    Discovery of Hyperstable Noncanonical Plant-Derived Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor Agonist and Analogs

    • Shining Loo
      Shining Loo
      School of Biological Sciences, Nanyang Technological University, 60 Nanyang Drive, Singapore 637551, Singapore

    Supporting Info (1)Â»Supporting Information Supporting Information
    SUBJECTS:
    • Peptides and proteins,
    • Agonists,
    • Assays,
    • Rodent models,
    • Biopolymers
    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Here, we report the discovery of the first plant-derived and noncanonical epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) agonist, the 36-residue bleogen pB1 from Pereskia bleo of the Cactaceae family. We show that bleogen pB1 is a low-affinity EGFR agonist using a suite of chemical, biochemical, cellular, and animal experiments which include incisor eruption and wound-healing mouse models. A focused positional scanning pB1 library of Ala- and d-amino acid scans yielded a high-affinity pB1 analog, [K29k]pB1, with a 60-fold-improved EGFR affinity and mitogenicity. We show that the potency of [K29k]pB1 and the epidermal growth factor (EGF) is comparable in a diabetic mouse wound-healing model. We also show that both bleogen pB1 and [K29k]pB1 are hyperstable, being >100-fold more stable than EGF against proteolytic degradation. Overall, our discovery of a noncanonical proteolytic-resistant EGFR agonist scaffold could open new avenues for developing wound healing and skin regeneration therapeutics and biomaterials.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Epidermal growth factor (EGF), the first growth factor discovered in 1960,(1â3) binds to the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR/ErbB1/HER), which initiates diverse cellular responses required for developmental growth.(1â12) All EGFR agonists share an EGF-like domain with a conserved cysteine motif, disulfide connectivity (Cys I-III, II-IV, V-VI), and a three-loop structure consisting of a double-stranded antiparallel Î²-sheet.(13) To date, there are seven related mammalian EGFR agonists ranging from 46 to 132 residues that have been identified. They include three high-affinity agonists: EGF, transforming growth factor-alpha (TGF-Î±), and heparin-binding epidermal growth factor (hb-EGF) and four low-affinity agonists: betacellulin, amphiregulin, epiregulin, and epigen.(1,12,14â20) Apart from mammals, EGFR agonists have been found in nearly all organisms, such as viruses, insects, and nematodes(12,21â24) but not in plants.
    EGF is clinically approved in several countries for treating diabetic foot ulcers.(25â28) Chronic wounds and their attendant consequences of severe pain, amputation, and disability remain an important health concern and an increasing socio-economic burden.(29,30) At least 15% of diabetic patients will develop chronic ulcers on their feet.(31â33) The total medical cost for managing this ailment was estimated US$ 9â13 billion in the United States.(34) In this regard, EGF, which plays important roles in proliferation, migration, and differentiation, offers promise as a therapeutic intervention for wound management.(35) However, the poor proteolytic stability of EGF in the microenvironment of chronic wounds tempered the enthusiasm of its clinical use since frequent applications are required to achieve the desired therapeutic effects.(36â38) Recent findings suggest that topical application of EGF combined with protease inhibitors could improve wound healing compared to EGF alone.(39,40) Thus, developing a protease-resistant EGF-like molecule for treating diabetes-associated chronic wounds remains an unmet need.
    Our laboratory has a strong interest in the discovery of naturally-occurring hyperstable cysteine-rich peptides (CRPs) in medicinal plants.(41â44) Previously, we identified a family of CRPs from the aqueous extracts of a cactus plant, Pereskia bleo, designated bleogens (Figure 1A,B).(42) Our work also shows that the prototypic bleogen pB1 is antifungal and belongs to the family of knottin-type plant cationic antimicrobial peptides.(42)Pereskia bleo (Kunth) DC of the Cactaceae family, also known as rose cactus, is a popular Southeast Asian medicinal herb. Their leaves are traditionally consumed in Singapore and Malaysia for treating gastritis, hemorrhoids, and ulcers,(45) suggesting the presence of putative wound-healing compounds in this cactus plant extract.
    Guided by its ethnomedicinal use for treating gastric ulcers, we found that bleogen pB1 could act as an EGFR agonist. However, all EGFR agonists contain a canonical EGF-like domain, but not the 36-residue bleogen pB1. Instead, it belongs to the 6-cysteine-hevein-like peptide (6C-HLP) family which has a different cysteine motif (CXnCXnCCXnCXnC) which produces a cystine-knot disulfide connectivity (Cys I-IV, II-V, III-VI),(42,46) resulting in a different, but far more, compact knotted structure than the canonical non-cystine-knot EGF-like domain.
    Herein, we show that bleogen pB1 is a hyperstable EGFR agonist which is experimentally supported by a panel of chemical, biochemical, cellular, and animal studies. In addition, structureâactivity relationship studies using position-scanning with Ala- and d-amino acids led to the discovery of a pB1 analog with a 60-fold increase in EGFR affinity and potency that is comparable to EGF in a wound-healing diabetic mouse model.

    Results

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Motif Search and Molecular Docking of Bleogen pB1 as an EGFR Agonist to Determine the âHot Spotâ for StructureâActivity Relationship Studies

    We used WebLogo to show the sequence similarities of the seven related mammalian EGFR agonists, including EGF, TGF-Î±, Hb-EGF, betacellulin, amphiregulin, epiregulin, and epigen. These seven EGFR agonists share four conserved noncysteine residues, three of which are located in loop C (Cys V-VI), forming a specific YXGXR motif (X, any amino acid) (Figures 1C and S1). The loop 4 of bleogen pB1 also contains a YXGXK motif, similar to the loop C of EGFR agonists in sequence and structure (Figure 1D). In silico modeling of bleogen pB1 and EGFR (PDB entry 1IVO, chain A) using the proteinâprotein docking server ClusPro version 2.0 showed that bleogen pB1 loop 4 could bind to EGFR at the same site as EGF loop C, suggesting a common âhot spotâ for binding to EGFR (Figure 1E).(47) Importantly, the discovery of this common âhot spotâ shared by pB1 and EGFR agonists provided grounds for our subsequent structureâactivity relationship studies.

    Synthesis and Characterization of Bleogen pB1

    For both in vitro and in vivo assays of EGF-like activities, we used primarily the natural bleogen pB1 isolated from the Pereskia plant. The natural bleogen pB1 was isolated from the aqueous leaf extracts of Pereskia bleo, using C-18 reversed-phase high performance liquid chromatography (RP-HPLC).(42) To prepare synthetic bleogen pB1, we used a stepwise solid-phase method and Fmoc chemistry (Figure 2A). After removing the protecting groups and cleaving the unprotected peptide from the resin support by trifluoroacetic acid (TFA), the crude pB1 product was oxidatively folded using a combination of redox reagents consisting of cysteamine and cystamine in a 10:1 molar ratio in 0.1 M ammonium bicarbonate, pH 8 for 1 h to give 70% yield of bleogen pB1. The purified synthetic and natural bleogen pB1 were indistinguishable as demonstrated by RP-HPLC, heparin-affinity chromatography, and 2D-nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) (Figures 2B,C, S2, and S3).
    To equip bleogen pB1 with a chemical affinity probe for target identification (Figure 2A), we used total synthesis again by coupling Fmoc-Lys(biotin) to the N-terminus of the protected pB1 peptide still attached to resin supports to give biotinylated-pB1 (biotin-pB1). These total syntheses provided unambiguous site-specific labeling of bleogen pB1 at its N-terminus to retain the integrity of their side chain functional groups.

    Bleogen pB1 Displays EGF-Like Biological Activities

    To determine whether bleogen pB1 is an EGF-like mitogen, we examined its biological effects on HaCaT (human keratinocyte) proliferation using EGF as a positive control. We showed that bleogen pB1 and EGF promotes HaCaT cell proliferation with an EC50 of 130 and 1.2 nM, respectively (Figure 3A,B). The 100-fold difference in mitogenic potency between EGF and pB1 suggests that bleogen pB1 belongs to the family of low-affinity EGFR agonists such as epigen and amphiregulin.(12,17,18,20) Both native and synthetic bleogen pB1 showed identical proliferative activities on HaCaT cells, confirming that the observed proliferative effects were not due to contaminants from the plant extracts (Figure 3B). As a negative control, the 3417 Da peptide aB1 isolated from Achyranthes bidentata, a 6C-HLP belonging to the same cysteine-rich peptide family as bleogen pB1 with a similar cysteine motif and disulfide connectivity, was not active up to 10 Î¼M in this assay (Figure S4). We also showed that bleogen pB1 promotes the proliferation of primary human keratinocytes (Figure 3C) and enhances DNA synthesis of HaCaT cells using 5-ethynyl-2â²-deoxyuridine (EdU) incorporation assay (Figure 3D). In addition, both EGF and bleogen pB1 accelerates HaCaT cell migration and endothelial cell tube formation (Figures S5 and S6).
    A hallmark EGF assay that led to its discovery is the incisor eruption in newborn mice.(1) We showed that subcutaneous injection of bleogen pB1 (3 mg/kg) or EGF (3 mg/kg) for five consecutive days accelerated the incisor eruption in newborn mice from 153 h (saline control) to 125 and 100 h, respectively (Figure 3E). We also showed that bleogen pB1 displays an in vivo wound-healing effect. Treatment of bleogen pB1 (10 nmol/wound) or EGF (1 nmol/wound) for three consecutive days accelerated wound healing from day 3 to day 11 using the full-thickness excision wound model in C57 mice (Figures 3F and S7).(48) Taken together, these six different in vitro and in vivo assays strongly support that bleogen pB1 is a mitogen and displays EGF-like biological activities.

    Bleogen pB1 Interacts with EGFR

    To show that the mitogenic activity of bleogen pB1 is a result of its interaction with EGFR, we used pull-down and neutralizing antibody assays to examine their interactions. Biotin-pB1 was able to pull-down EGFR, suggesting their putative ligandâreceptor interaction (Figure 4A). Coincubation of an EGFR neutralizing monoclonal antibody (clone LA1), which binds to the ectodomain of EGFR, blocked bleogen pB1-induced HaCaT cell proliferation (Figure 4B). These results strongly supported that the interaction between bleogen pB1 and EGFR is specific, and the proliferative effect is EGFR-dependent.

    Proliferative Effect of Bleogen pB1 Is Associated with the EGFR/MEK/ERK Signaling Pathway

    EGF activates the EGFR/MEK/ERK signaling pathway which has an important role in regulating cell proliferation.(49) We explored whether bleogen pB1 would undergo a similar EGF signaling pathway to induce keratinocyte proliferation. We found that bleogen pB1 induces the phosphorylation of EGFR, MEK1/2, and ERK1/2 (Figure 5A,B). Furthermore, coincubation with a small molecule selective EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor (AG1478) or selective MEK inhibitor (U0126) substantially inhibited the proliferative effects of bleogen pB1 in HaCaT cells (Figure 5C,D). Collectively, these results suggest that bleogen pB1 binds to EGFR and activates the EGFR/MEK/ERK signaling pathway to trigger HaCaT cell proliferation.
    EGF is known to activate transcription factors that bind to the serum response element (SRE) and initiate transcription of immediate early genes involved in the regulation of EGFR-mediated cell proliferation, such as c-fos and c-Jun.(50) We showed that bleogen pB1, dose-dependently increases the luciferase activity, similar to EGF in a stably expressed SRE-luciferase reporter HaCaT cell line (Figure 5E), indicating that bleogen pB1 stimulates SRE-mediated gene transcription. We also examined the effects of EGF- and bleogen pB1-induced transcriptional response on the expressions of EGF-associated immediate early genes using qPCR.(51) We confirmed that both bleogen pB1 and EGF significantly upregulate the mRNA expressions of c-fos and c-Jun in HaCaT cells (Figure 5F). Taken together, this series of experiments provided additional support for the similarity of EGF- and pB1-induced signaling pathways and transcriptional response.

    Position-Scanning of the Loop 4-Containing YAGQK Motif in Bleogen pB1 Using Ala- and d-Amino Acid

    In the previous section, we hypothesized that the YXGXK/R motif (X, any amino acid) in the loop 4 of bleogen pB1 and the loop C of canonical EGFR agonists could be a âhot spotâ for EGFR interaction (Figure 6A). Previously, we demonstrated that mutations of Y38 and R42 in TGF-Î± YXGXR motif loop C using the Ala- or d-amino acid scan resulted in a substantial decrease in both EGFR affinity and EGF-like mitogenic potential.(52,53) Accordingly, we chemically synthesized a focused Ala- and d-amino acid library of the corresponding âhot spotâ of bleogen pB1, YAGQK loop 4 (Figure 6A). They include the Ala-substituted series of [Y25A]pB1, [G27A]pB1, [Q28A]pB1, and [K29A]pB1 and the d-amino acid-substituted series of [Y25y]pB1, [A26a]pB1, [Q28q]pB1, and [K29k]pB1.
    Each peptide was compared with bleogen pB1 in two different studies. We first tested its EGFR affinity using time-resolved fluorescence energy transfer (TR-FRET)-based competitive displacement using purified human EGFR-Fc and then its mitogenicity using HaCaT cell proliferation assay. Our results showed that bleogen pB1 displaces biotin-EGF with an IC50 of 1720 Â± 0.075 nM, whereas EGF with an IC50 of 31 Â± 0.016 nM (Figure 6B). All Ala-analogs showed a decrease in EGF-like biological activities using both EGFR displacement and cell proliferation assays (Figures S8 and S9). In contrast, two d-analogs, [K29k]pB1 and [Y25y]pB1, displayed higher affinity than bleogen pB1, with an IC50 of 27 Â± 0.050 nM and 580 Â± 0.089 nM, respectively. Compared to bleogen pB1, [K29k]pB1 is approximately 60-fold more potent (Figures 6C and S10). We showed that biotin-[K29k]pB1 and biotin-[Y25y]pB1, chemically synthesized as described previously for biotin-pB1, interact with EGFR using a pull-down assay (Figure S11). To confirm our data, we showed that [K29k]pB1 and [Y25y]pB1 are 43 and 25% more mitogenic than bleogen pB1, and their mitogenic effects can be inhibited by EGFR neutralizing antibodies (clone LA1), indicating that their activity is EGFR-dependent (Figures 6D and S12).

    Bleogen pB1 Accelerates Wound Healing in the Excisional Wound Model Using Streptozotocin-Induced Diabetic Mice

    To determine whether the improved in vitro mitogenicity of [K29k]pB1 would correspond to the in vivo assays, we used a delayed wound-healing streptozotocin (STZ)-induced diabetic mice model. Diabetes was induced in C57 mice by two intraperitoneal injections (80 mg/kg) of STZ on day 1 and 5. Starting from day 8, blood glucose was monitored regularly for 2 weeks. Mice with blood glucose levels above 11.1 mmol/L were considered diabetic and subjected to the splinted excisional wound-healing model.(54) We showed that wound closure for STZ-induced diabetic mice is significantly delayed as compared to nondiabetic mice (Figure S13). We also showed that wounds topically treated with EGF (1 nmol/wound), bleogen pB1 (1 nmol/wound), or [K29k]pB1 (1 nmol/wound) for five consecutive days healed at a significantly faster rate starting from day 4 post injury compared to the vehicle control group, macroscopically (Figure 7A,B). Notably, [K29k]pB1 promoted wound closure at a similar rate as EGF and much faster than bleogen pB1. These in vivo results are in agreement with our in vitro assays on EGFR affinity and mitogenicity, suggesting that [K29k]pB1 is as potent as EGF.

    Bleogen pB1 and [K29k]pB1 Are Hyperstable against Proteolytic Degradation

    To determine whether bleogen pB1 and [K29k]pB1, which are structurally more compact than EGF, are also more resistant than EGF against enzymatic, heat, and acid degradation, we performed peptide stability assays. All three tested peptides, bleogen pB1, [K29k]pB1, and EGF, are relatively stable to acid (0.2 M HCl) with a calculated t1/2 > 500 min (Figure S14). Bleogen pB1 and [K29k]pB1 were at least 20-fold more stable than EGF in heat treatment (100 Â°C) with a calculated t1/2 > 500 min (Figure 8A). More importantly, we also subjected them to a panel of proteases with different cleavage site preferences to test their proteolytic stability. They include pepsin, human serum, trypsin, pronase, and human neutrophil elastase (Figure 8BâF). The t1/2 of bleogen pB1 and [K29k]pB1 were calculated to be >500 min in our panel of proteases (including trypsin, pepsin, neutrophil elastase, and pronase) and > 800 h in human serum. In contrast, the t1/2 of EGF ranged from 0.9 to 23.5 min in our panel proteases and 3.1 h in human serum. Hence, bleogen pB1 and [K29k]pB1 were found to be at least 100-fold more stable under proteolytic conditions as compared to EGF. The control peptide, the S-alkylated bleogen pB1, with all its disulfide bridges reduced and S-alkylated by iodoacetamide, was degraded by proteases including trypsin, pepsin, neutrophil elastase, and pronase within 1 min, suggesting that the disulfide-knotted structure of bleogen pB1 and [K29k]pB1 is essential to maintain their structural integrity and resistance against proteolytic degradation.

    Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Here, we used a comprehensive panel of in vitro and in vivo experiments to support our identification of a novel EGFR agonist, bleogen pB1, derived from the medicinal plant Pereskia bleo. Bleogen pB1 does not contain an EGF-like domain and thus represents a first-in-class EGFR agonist, 60 years after the discovery of EGF.(1â3) The 36-residue antifungal bleogen pB1 is also the smallest naturally occurring and the first plant-derived peptidyl EGFR agonist reported to date.
    Similar to EGF, bleogen pB1 promotes keratinocyte proliferation, keratinocyte migration, and endothelial tube formation. pB1 interacts with EGFR, as shown by EGFR pull-down, competitive inhibition using the EGFR-neutralizing antibody and competitive EGF-displacement experiments. In addition, bleogen pB1 activates the EGFR/MEK/ERK signaling pathway and downstream gene transcription to induce keratinocyte proliferation. Incisor eruption in new born mice and wound healing in mouse models are hallmarks of the in vivo functions of EGF,(1,26) and similar to EGF, pB1 also acts as an EGFR agonist. These experiments provide strong support that bleogen pB1 is an EGFR agonist. Future studies on the receptor specificity and global comparisons between pB1 and EGF through gene, protein, and metabolite profiling are warranted to pinpoint the biomarkers in relation to their proliferative effects.
    Bleogen pB1 is 50-to-100-fold less potent than EGF using a receptor displacement assay, putting it in the similar rank of amphiregulin and epiregulin as a low-affinity EGFR agonist. To determine which amino acid in bleogen pB1 is important for EGFR activity, we used literature precedents, sequence homology, and molecular modeling experiments to guide our pB1 analog studies. The loop 4 of bleogen pB1 shares high sequence identity and structure similarity to the C loop of EGF/TGF-Î± (Figures 1C,D and 6A). Molecular modeling experiments confirmed that the loop 4 of bleogen pB1 is the contact region for the EGF receptor (Figure 9). In particular, the conserved YXGXK/R motif in loop 4 of bleogen pB1 could be the âhot spotâ for the pB1-EGFR interaction.
    For our structure-relationship activity studies of bleogen pB1 loop 4, we used complementary positional Ala- and d-amino acid scans previously developed by our laboratory.(52,53,55,56) Positional scans have found success in the structureâactivity relationship studies of the EGF-like myxoma virus growth factor, TGF-Î±, and endothelin.(52,53,55,56) The Ala-scan provides information on the relationship between biological activities and side-chain compositions.(57,58) In contrast, the d-amino acid scan has the advantage of retaining hydrodynamic properties of the analogs. More importantly, the different stereochemistries of the d- and l-configuration could reveal the importance of side-chain orientation as a receptor-contact amino acid.(55,58â62)
    Previous studies on positional scanning of TGF-Î± showed that mutations, particularly Y38 and R42 in the YXGXR loop C of TGF-Î±, substantially decreased both EGFR affinity and mitogenicity in A431 cells.(52,53) Likewise, a separate study on EGF showed that replacement of Y37 and R41 by Ala sharply decreased EGF-like activities.(47,63â66) In agreement with these studies, our positional scanning using Ala on the conserved YAGQK motif in loop 4 of bleogen pB1 also resulted in a decrease of EGF-like activities for all the Ala-substituted pB1 analogs.(47,52,53,63â66) In contrast, d-amino acid positional scanning resulted in an increase in EGF-like activity for two pB1 analogs, [K29k]pB1 and [Y25y]pB1. Replacing Lys at position 29 by d-Lys in [K29k]pB1 resulted in a 60-fold improvement in binding to EGFR. This enhanced binding affinity of [K29k]pB1 puts it as a high-affinity EGFR agonist that is as potent as EGF, effectively converting pB1 from a low- to a high-affinity EGFR agonist. Using a STZ-diabetic mouse model, we confirmed our in vitro results and showed that the wound-healing potency of [K29k]pB1 and EGF are comparable.
    Two factors likely contribute to the 60-fold improved EGF-like activities of [K29k]pB1. First, molecular modeling experiments showed that changing the chirality of K29 alters its side chain orientation and more importantly, decreases the contact distance between k29 of [K29k]pB1 and D355 in the active-site of EGFR from 4.0 to 2.8 Ã, resulting in a stronger electrostatic interaction of k29-D355 (Figure 9).(47) Second, compared to the l-amino acid, the backbone torsion angles for the d-amino acid are more favorable as turn-forming residues.(67) This could eventually promote the formation of local intramolecular hydrogen bonding surrounding the turn-forming residues, which in turn, stabilizes the reverse-turn at k29.(67) Thus, k29 in [K29k]pB1 aids in stabilizing the active conformation of loop 4 to allow efficient contact with D355 in the EGFR binding pocket, resulting in improved EGFR affinity and EGF-like wound-healing efficacy.
    An important finding of this report is that bleogen pB1 and [K29k]pB1 are >100-fold more stable than EGF against proteolytic degradation. Both EGF and bleogens are three-disulfide-containing peptides, but their similarity ends there. Bleogen pB1 differs from EGF in three distinct features. First, pB1 contains an N-terminal pyroglutamate, which renders it resistant to aminopeptidase degradation. Such a feature is not found in EGF. Second, the 36-residue pB1 is 17 residues shorter than the 53-residue EGF, making the pB1 structure more compact than EGF. However, a major contributing factor is found in the third feature. Bleogen pB1 is a cystine-knot peptide which is characterized by one disulfide bond threading through the other two to create an intramolecular âknotâ with three disulfides.(41,42,44,68,69) This knotted structure produces a single-domain pB1 that is highly compact. In contrast, EGF and all EGF domains have a two subdomain structure, consisting of the N-terminal A-/B-loop formed by the first two disulfide bonds and the C-terminal C-loop formed by the third disulfide bond (Figure S15).(70) The combinations of these features contribute to the hyperstability of bleogen pB1 against proteolytic degradation. Introducing a d-Lys in [K29k]pB1 may provide additional resistance against trypsin degradation. However, our result showed that removing the cross-bracing disulfide bridges of pB1 as structural constraints by S-alkylation leads to complete proteolytic degradation by enzymes such as trypsin, pepsin, pronase, and neutrophil elastase within 1 min. These data are consistent with numerous published reports on the contribution of cystine-knot to the hyperstability of plant cystine-knot peptides of 30â40 amino acids.(41â44,68,69) Indeed, many groups including ours have exploited the hyperstability of the cystine-knot peptide as scaffolds in drug design.(71,72) An example from our laboratory is grafting the protease-susceptible linear bradykinin antagonists into the cystine-knot scaffold to give orally active analgesics.(72)
    The proteolytic susceptibility of EGF in the wound microenvironment limits its clinical applications. To extend the half-life of EGF against proteolysis in wounds, Okumura et al. (1990) used a mixture of protease inhibitors with EGF to reduce its degradation, leading to an increased rate of wound healing.(40) Recently, other groups explored polymer-based systems, encapsulation, and nanomaterials to increase the half-life of EGF.(73â76) The exceptional proteolytic stability displayed by bleogen pB1 and its analog could provide a direct solution to overcome the short half-life of EGF-like molecules in managing chronic wounds. Furthermore, the innate antifungal properties of bleogen pB1 could be an added advantage. To showcase the proteolytic stability of [K29k]pB1 in wound healing, future studies using alternative animal models are rendered, such as pigs of similar skin characteristics as human, with an epidermal turnover time of 30 days compared to 8â10 days in mice.
    In conclusion, the discovery of bleogen pB1 representing a first-in-class hyperstable, noncanonical, and plant-derived EGFR agonist could fuel further interest in developing EGFR agonists and antagonists for basic and translational research. In addition, our discovery of an improved pB1 analog [K29k]pB1, which is equally potent as EGF, could advance the development of potent therapeutic analogs for wound healing, regenerative medicine, and skincare.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Materials

    All the chemicals and solvents, unless otherwise stated, were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, US, and Fisher Scientific, US. The anti-EGFR-neutralizing monoclonal antibody, clone LA1, which binds to the external domain of human EGFR and competes with EGF and TGF-Î±, was purchased from Merck Millipore, US.(77,78) AG1478, a selective EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor with no activity on ErbB2, was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, US.(79) U0126, a highly selective inhibitor of MEK-1 and MEK-2, was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, US.(80)

    Extraction and Purification of Natural Bleogen pB1

    Fresh Pereskia bleo leaves were collected from the Nanyang Community Herb Garden at Nanyang Technological University, Singapore (courtesy of Mr. Ng Kim Chuan). Fresh leaves (1 kg) of Pereskia bleo were blended with water for 15 min and centrifuged at 9000 rpm for 10 min at 4 Â°C (Beckman Coulter, US) and the supernatant was filtered through 1 Î¼m pore size glass fiber filter paper (Sartorius, Singapore). The filtrate was then loaded onto a C18 flash column (Grace Davison, US) and eluted with 60% ethanol. The eluted fractions were then loaded onto an SP Sepharose resin column (GE Healthcare, UK), eluted with 1 M NaCl (pH 3.0), and followed by ultrafiltration (Vivaflow 200, 2000 MWCO hydrostat). Further purification was performed by RP-HPLC and heparin-affinity chromatography (Shimadzu, Japan). Matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization-time of flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS) was used to identify the presence of bleogen pB1 in the eluted fractions. The eluted fractions were lyophilized for storage at room temperature.

    In Silico Modeling

    To model the interactions between the NMR structure of bleogen pB1 and the crystal structure of human EGFR (PDB entry: 1VIO), the proteinâprotein docking server ClusPro version 2.0 was used. The docking involves global rigid docking using the fast Fourier transform correlation approach. Two sets of 900 lowest energy structures (using electrostatic energy, van der Waals attractions, and van der Waals repulsions) were retained. The second step included clustering the retained structure using pairwise RMSD. Minimizing energy of the complexes, the 10 largest clusters were refined. Clusters ranked the highest displayed the most contacts with the protein.

    Solid-Phase Peptide Synthesis and Oxidative Folding of Bleogen pB1

    Synthetic bleogen pB1, its Ala-analogs ([Y25A]pB1, [G27A]pB1, [Q28A]pB1, and [K29A]pB1), and d-analogs ([Y25y]pB1, [A26a]pB1, [Q28q]pB1, and [K29k]pB1) were manually synthesized by Fmoc-based solid phase peptide synthesis on Wang resin at room temperature. The synthesized peptides were cleaved in a cleavage cocktail (92.5% TFA; 2.5% H2O; 2.5% 1,2-ethanedithiol; 2.5% triisopropylsilane) at room temperature for 1 h. The crude cleaved products were then folded under the following folding conditions: 10% DMSO, 90% 0.1 M NH4HCO3 aq. with pH at 8.0, and cystamine (10 equivalent) and cysteamine (100 equivalent) for 1 h at room temperature. The folded pB1 and its Ala- and d-analogs were purified by preparative HPLC (250 Ã 21 mm, 5 Î¼m) (Phenomenex, US) and identified using MALDI-TOF MS (Figure S16âS33). A linear gradient of mobile phase A (0.1% TFA/H2O) and mobile phase B (0.1% TFA/ acetonitrile (ACN)) were used. The folding yield was calculated to be 70% by HPLC analyses. HPLC and MALDI-TOF MS were used to show that the tested compounds are of at least 95% purity. 1H NMR, RP-HPLC, and heparin affinity chromatography were performed to demonstrate the integrity of synthetic bleogen pB1 as compared to its native form.
    N-terminal biotin labeling of pB1, [Y25y]pB1, and [K29k]pB1 was performed on peptide resin with a mixture of Fmoc-lysin(biotin)-OH (4.0 eq.), N,N-diisopropylethylamine (DIPEA; 6.0 eq.), (benzotriazol-1-yloxy)tripyrrolidinophosphonium hexafluorophosphate (PyBOP; 4.0 eq.) in 50% dimethylformamide (DMF), and 50% 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (NMP) for 2 h at room temperature. After 2 h of reaction, the biotin-labeled pB1 was cleaved and oxidatively folded under the conditions described previously. The folded biotin-pB1 was purified by preparative HPLC and identified using MALDI-TOF MS (Figure S34âS36).

    Cell Culture and Transfection

    HaCaT and HUVEC-CS (endothelial cells) cells were cultured in Dulbeccoâs Modified Eagleâs Medium (DMEM) supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum and 100 U/mL of penicillin and streptomycin. Normal Human Epidermal Keratinocytes adult purchased from Lifeline Cell Technology were cultured in Lifeline DermaLife K medium. They were grown in a 5% CO2 humidified incubator at 37 Â°C. HaCaT cells were stably transfected with pGL4.33[luc2P/SRE/Hygro] (Promega) and selected using 250 Î¼g/mL hygromycin. Stable HaCaT cells expressing the SRE luciferase reporter were maintained with 250 Î¼g/mL hygromycin.

    Cell Proliferation Assay

    Cell proliferation was determined using crystal violet staining. Briefly, 1.0 Ã 104 HaCaT cells per well were seeded in a 96-well plate with bleogen pB1 or EGF (positive control) or 3417 Da peptide aB1 (negative control) in serum-free medium. 3417 Da peptide aB1 is a CRP isolated from Achyranthes bidentata with the amino acid sequence NCESGTSCIPGAQHNCCSGVCVPIVTIFYGVCY (Figure S37). Crystal violet staining was performed as previously described. Briefly, after the incubation period, the wells were fixed with 4% buffered paraformaldehyde for 20 min. The cells were then stained with 0.25% crystal violet in 20% methanol for 15 min. The excess crystal violet stain was rinsed with distilled water for 4â5 times and air-dried. Glacial acetic acid (10%) in Milli-Q water was added to extract the crystal violet stain. The absorbance was then measured at 595 nm using a microplate reader (Tecan Infinite 200 Pro, Switzerland).

    EdU Incorporation Assay

    EdU incorporation assay was performed using an EdU proliferative kit (iFluor 488) according to manufacturerâs instructions. Briefly, 2.5 Ã 104 HaCaT cells per well were seeded in a 96-well plate. After overnight incubation, the cells were incubated with EdU (10 Î¼M) for 4 h with bleogen pB1 or EGF in serum-free medium. Cells were then fixed, permeabilized, and incubated in a reaction mix containing iFluor 488 for 30 min. The nuclei were stained using DAPI. The plates were visualized using a fluorescence microscope.

    Cell Migration Assay

    Cell migration was monitored using the scratch assay. Briefly, HaCaT cells were seeded into 2-well silicone inserts with a defined gap of 500 Î¼m (ibidi, Germany). After overnight incubation, the inserts were removed and incubated with bleogen pB1 or EGF in DMEM medium containing 0.1% FBS. After incubation for 8 h, the wells were photographed using an inverted phase-contrast microscope. Images were analyzed for the percentage of cell-free area using a Wimasis image analysis platform.

    Endothelial Tube Formation Assay

    Endothelial tube formation assay was performed using a Î¼-slide (ibidi, Germany). Briefly, 10 Î¼L of gel matrix (BD Matrigel Basement Membrane Matrix) was cast onto each Î¼-slide well and left to solidify. HUVEC-CS cells were seeded per well at a density of 2500 cells/well together with bleogen pB1 or EGF. After incubation for 2 h, the wells were photographed using an inverted phase-contrast microscope. Images were analyzed for the numbering of branching points using a Wimasis image analysis platform.

    Pull-Down Assay

    Pull-down assay was performed using NeutrAvidin UltraLink Resin (Thermo Fisher Scientific, US). Briefly, the resin was washed with phosphate buffered saline (PBS) three times and incubated with biotin-pB1/biotin-[K29k]pB1/biotin-[Y25y]pB1, biotin (negative control), biotin-aB1 (negative control, Figure S38), or biotin-EGF (positive control) at room temperature with rotation for 2 h. Bovine serum albumin (BSA) (2%) in PBS was added to both tubes and incubated at room temperature with gentle end-over-end mixing for another 2 h. HaCaT cell lysate (600 Î¼g) was added to each tube and allowed to incubate overnight at 4 Â°C with rotation. After incubation, the resin was transferred to Pierce spin columns and washed 10 times with PBS. A 6Ã loading dye with Î²-mercaptoethanol was added to the resin and heated for 10 min at 85 Â°C. The resultant mixture was centrifuged at 200 g for 1 min and resolved using 8% sodium dodecyl sulfate polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE) at 100 V constant for 120 min. Blot transfer was performed on a polyvinylidiene difluoride (PVDF) membrane (GE healthcare, Sweden) at 250 mA for 120 min on ice. The blot was blocked with 5% BSA tris-buffered saline and Tween 20 (TBST) before incubating overnight at 4 Â°C with anti-EGFR anti-rabbit antibodies (1:1000 in 5% BSA TBST; Cell Signaling, US). After incubation overnight, the membrane was washed with TBST at room temperature for three times at 10 min each. The blot was then incubated with secondary anti-rabbit horseradish peroxidase (HRP) (Cell Signaling, US) (1:5000 in 5% BSA TBST) and was incubated for another 1 h at room temperature. The blot was washed five times 10 min each with TBST at room temperature before the addition of the chemiluminescence substrate (Advansta, US) and exposure on X-ray films (Fujifilm, Japan). Densitometric analysis was performed using Fiji (National Institutes of Health, US). The expression of P-ERK1/2 or P-MEK1/2 was presented as relative to the expression of T-ERK1/2 or P-MEK1/2, respectively.

    Immunoprecipitation

    Immunoprecipitation was performed using EGFR (D38B1) rabbit monoclonal antibodies conjugated to magnetic beads (Cell Signaling, US). Briefly, the magnetic beads were washed with PBS three times and 50 Î¼g HaCaT cell lysate was added to each tube and allowed to incubate overnight at 4 Â°C with rotation. After incubation, the magnetic beads were washed five times with PBS. A 6Ã loading dye with Î²-mercaptoethanol was added to the resin and heated for 10 min at 85 Â°C. The resultant mixture was centrifuged at 14000 g Ã 1 min and resolved using 10% SDS-PAGE at a 100 V constant for 120 min. Blot transfer was performed on a PVDF membrane (GE healthcare, Sweden) at 250 mA for 120 min on ice. The blot was blocked with 5% BSA TBST before incubating overnight at 4 Â°C with anti-phosphotyrosine-HRP (R&D systems, US) or anti-EGFR anti-rabbit antibodies (1:1000 in 5% BSA TBST; Cell Signaling, US). After incubation, the membrane was washed with TBST at room temperature for three times at 10 min each. The blot was then incubated with secondary anti-rabbit horseradish peroxidase (HRP) (1:5000 in 5% BSA TBST) and was incubated for another 1 h at room temperature. The blot was washed five times 10 min each with TBST at room temperature before the addition of the chemiluminescence substrate (Advansta, US) and exposure on X-ray films (Fujifilm, Japan).

    Western Blot Analyses

    Blot transfer was performed onto a PVDF membrane (GE healthcare, Sweden) at 250 mA for 120 min on ice. The blot was blocked with 5% BSA TBST before incubating overnight at 4 Â°C with the anti-P-MEK1/2 rabbit antibody (1:2000 in 5% BSA TBST; Cell Signaling, US), anti-MEK1/2 rabbit antibody (1:2000 in 5% BSA TBST; Cell Signaling, US), anti-P-ERK1/2 rabbit antibody (1:2000 in 5% BSA TBST; Cell Signaling, US), anti-ERK1/2 rabbit antibody (1:2000 in 5% BSA TBST; Cell Signaling, US), and anti-Î²-actin mouse antibody (1:10000 in 5% BSA TBST; Merck Millipore, US). After incubation, the membrane was washed with TBST at room temperature three times for 10 min each. The blot was then incubated with secondary anti-mouse or anti-rabbit HRP (1:5000 in 5% BSA TBST; Cell Signaling, US) and was incubated for another 1 h at room temperature. The blot was washed five times 10 min each with TBST at room temperature before addition of the chemiluminescence substrate (Advansta, US) and exposure on X-ray films (Fujifilm, Japan).

    TR-FRET EGFR Ligand Binding Assay

    Competitive displacement assay was performed using the EGF-EGFR LANCE Ultra TR-FRET Binding Kit as per manufacturerâs instructions (PerkinElmer, US). Streptavidin is conjugated with a LANCE Europium chelate which binds to biotin-EGF, while EGFR-Fc interacts with anti-human IgG that is labeled with the ULight dye. Briefly, different concentrations of bleogen pB1 or its Ala- or d-amino acid analogs or EGF were mixed with the working solution and incubated at room temperature for 2 h. The TR-FRET ratio was measured using a microplate reader in a dual emission mode (excitation: 340 nm, emission: 665 nm and 615 nm) (Cytation 1, US). The results were presented as the relative binding percentage of biotin-EGF. aB1 with an amino acid sequence of NCESGTSCIPGAQHNCCSGVCVPIVTIFYGVCY or roseltide rT7 with an amino acid sequence of CVSSGIVDACSECCEPDKCIIMLPTWPPRYVCSV (Figure S39) was used as the negative control. EGF was used as the positive control.

    Luciferase Reporter Assay

    Stable HaCaT cells expressing the SRE luciferase reporter were tested for bioluminescence response on treatment with bleogen pB1 and EGF as the positive control. Briefly, the cells were cultured in a white 96-well plate to achieve 90% confluency. The cells were washed with serum-free medium, starved overnight in serum-free DMEM medium, and treated with bleogen pB1 and EGF for 6 h. The luciferase assay was performed using the ONE-Glo EX Luciferase Assay System (Promega, US) as per manufacturerâs instructions. Luminescence was measured using a microplate reader (Tecan Infinite 200 Pro, Switzerland).

    Gene Expression Analysis

    Total RNA was extracted from HaCaT and primary human keratinocytes using the PureLink RNA Mini Kit (Thermo Fisher Scientific, US). First-strand cDNA was synthesized from 600 ng of total RNA using SuperScript II Reverse Transcriptase and Oligo(dT)12â18 (Thermo Fisher Scientific, US) according to manufacturerâs instructions. Quantitative PCR (qPCR) was performed with iTaq Universal SYBR Green Supermix (Bio-Rad, US) on a CFX96 Touch Real-Time PCR Detection System (Bio-Rad, US) for 40 cycles. PCR reaction (20 Î¼L): 3 Î¼L cDNA, 1 Î¼L primer mix (10 Î¼M), 6 Î¼L DEPC-treated water, and 10 Î¼L mastermix. The predesigned primer pairs (Origene, US) used in the qPCR reactions are as following: c-fos (NM_005252) were 5â²-GCC TCT CTT ACT ACC ACT CAC C-3â² (forward) and 5â²-AGA TGG CAG TGA CCG TGG GAA T-3â² (reverse); c-Jun (NM_002228) were 5â²- CCT TGA AAG CTC AGA ACT CGG AG-3â² (forward) and 5â²-TGC TGC GTT AGC ATG AGT TGG C-3â² (reverse); reference gene GAPDH (NM_ 001256799) were 5â²-GTC TCC TCT GAC TTC AAC AGC G-3â² (forward) and 5â²- ACC ACC CTG TTG CTG TAG CCA A-3â² (reverse). GAPDH was used as a housekeeping gene for normalization. Fold changes of gene expressions with c-fos and c-Jun were calculated using the 2âÎÎCT method.

    Full-Thickness Splinted Excisional Wounding of Mice

    C57BL/6 mice were obtained from Vital Rital Laboratories (Beijing, China). Mice were housed in plastic cages at 23 Â± 1 Â°C with a 12 h light/dark cycle and free access to water and food. All experiments were approved and performed in accordance with the institutional guidelines of the Experimental Animal Center of the Chinese Academy of Medical Science (Beijing, China).
    Full-thickness 5 mm splinted excisional wounding of mice was performed. Briefly, mice were anesthetized using an intraperitoneal injection of sodium pentobarbital (50 mg kgâ1). The hair of the back was shaved with an electric clipper followed by a depilatory cream. Using a 5 mm diameter sterile biopsy punch, symmetrical full-thickness excisional wounds were created. Splints were placed around the wound using adhesive glue and secured with four interrupted sutures. The wounds and splints were covered with Tegaderm (3 M, US). At indicated days within the 14 days post injury course, wound diameters were measured. The size of the wound was calculated from the average of two diameter measurements along the x- and y-axis.

    Treatment Regimen for Full-Thickness Splinted Excisional Wound Healing in C57BL/6 Mice

    Full-thickness 5 mm splinted excisional wounding of mice was performed on C57BL/6 mice as described above. Post injury, saline (vehicle control; n = 30 wounds; 15 mice), EGF (1 nmol/wound, positive control; n = 10 wounds; 5 mice), and bleogen pB1 (10 nmol/wound; n = 10 wounds; 5 mice) were administered to the wounds for three consecutive days. All experiments were approved and performed in accordance with the institutional guidelines of the Experimental Animal Center of the Chinese Academy of Medical Science (Beijing, China).

    Treatment Regimen for Full-Thickness Splinted Excisional Wound Healing in Streptozotocin-Induced Diabetic C57BL/6 Mice

    Diabetes was induced into C57BL/6 mice by two intraperitoneal injection (80 mg/kg) of STZ at day 1 and 5. Starting from day 8, blood glucose was monitored regularly for 2 weeks. Mice with blood glucose level above 11.1 mmol/L were considered as diabetic and subjected to full-thickness 5 mm splinted excisional wounding as described above (total 24 mice, two wounds per mice). Post injury, saline (vehicle control; n = 12 wounds), bleogen pB1 (1 nmol/wound; n = 12 wounds), [K29k]pB1 (1 nmol/wound; n = 12 wounds), and EGF (1 nmol/wound; n = 12 wounds) were topically administered to the wounds for five consecutive days. Blood glucose was also monitored at day 14 post injury to ensure the mice are diabetic.

    Newborn Mice Model for Incisor Eruption

    ICR mice were obtained from Vital Rital Laboratories (Beijing, China). Mice were housed in plastic cages at 23 Â± 1 Â°C with a 12 h light/dark cycle and free access to water and food. Subcutaneous injections were made for five consecutive days in the nape of the neck of the newborn mice starting from the day of birth (day 0). A total of 30 newborn mice were randomly separated into three test groups as follows: PBS, EGF (3 mg/kg), and bleogen pB1 (3 mg/kg). Incisor eruption was recorded daily by visual inspection. Incisor eruption was defined as the time at which a given tooth first pierced the oral epithelium.

    Peptide Stability Assay

    Heat Stability

    A concentration of 0.1 M purified bleogen pB1, [K29k]pB1, S-alkylated pB1 (iodoacetamido-), EGF, PBS (control) was incubated at 100 Â°C. Samples were collected at various time points (0, 30, 60, and 120 min).

    Acid Stability

    A concentration of 0.1 M purified bleogen pB1, [K29k]pB1, S-alkylated pB1 (iodoacetamido-), and EGF was dissolved in 0.2 M HCl and incubated at 37 Â°C. Samples were collected at various time points.

    Pepsin Stability

    A concentration of 0.1 M purified bleogen pB1, [K29k]pB1, S-alkylated pB1 (iodoacetamido-), and EGF was dissolved in 0.2 M HCl and incubated with pepsin (Roche Applied Science, US) in a 50:1 (w/v) ratio at 37 Â°C. Samples were collected at various time points.

    Pronase Stability

    A concentration of 0.1 M purified bleogen pB1, [K29k]pB1, S-alkylated pB1 (iodoacetamido-), and EGF was dissolved in PBS and incubated with pronase (0.2 mg/mL; Roche Applied Science, US) at 37 Â°C. Samples were collected at various time points.

    Neutrophil Elastase Stability

    A concentration of 0.1 M purified bleogen pB1, [K29k]pB1, S-alkylated pB1 (iodoacetamido-), and EGF was dissolved in PBS and incubated with human neutrophil elastase (0.05 mg/mL; Molecular Innovations, US) at 37 Â°C. Samples were collected at various time points.

    Trypsin Stability

    A concentration of 0.1 M purified bleogen pB1, [K29k]pB1, S-alkylated pB1 (iodoacetamido-), and EGF was dissolved in PBS and incubated with trypsin (0.2 mg/mL; Sigma-Aldrich, US) at 37 Â°C. Samples were collected at various time points.

    Human Serum Stability

    A concentration of 0.1 M purified bleogen pB1, [K29k]pB1, S-alkylated pB1 (iodoacetamido-), and EGF were prepared in 25% human serum in DMEM without phenol red. The test samples were incubated at 37 Â°C. Samples were collected at various time points. The collected samples were subjected to protein precipitation with 100% ethanol and centrifugation at 180,000 g for 5 min at 4 Â°C. The supernatant was collected for analysis.

    Analysis for Stability Assays

    All collected samples from various stability assays were analyzed by RP-HPLC with a linear gradient of mobile phase A (0.05% TFA/H2O) and mobile phase B (0.05% TFA/ACN) on an Aeris PEPTIDE XB-C18 column (Phenomenex, US). The resulting peaks were collected and identified by MALDI-TOF MS. The results were expressed as the percentage of initial concentration using the peak area of the HPLC profile.

    Statistical Analyses

    Statistical comparisons were performed using GraphPad version 8.2.1 (US). Data were analyzed using one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) followed by NewmanâKeuls post hoc tests. Data were expressed as mean Â± S.D. and p < 0.05 was considered to be statistically significant.

    cysteine-rich peptides

    DIPEA

    N,N-diisopropylethylamine

    DMEM

    Dulbeccoâs Modified of Eagleâs Medium

    DMF

    dimethylformamide

    DMSO

    dimethyl sulfoxide

    EdU

    5-ethynyl-2â²-deoxyuridine

    EGF

    epidermal growth factor

    EGFR

    epidermal growth factor receptor

    hb-EGF

    heparin-binding epidermal growth factor

    HRP

    horseradish peroxidase

    NMP

    1-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone

    NMR

    2D-nuclear magnetic resonance

    PG

    protecting Group

    PVDF

    polyvinylidiene difluoride

    PyBOP

    (benzotria-zol-1-yloxy)tripyrrolidinophosphonium hexafluorophosphate

    SDS-PAGE

    sodium dodecyl sulfate polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis

    SRE

    serum response element

    STZ

    streptozotocin

    TBST

    tris-buffered saline and Tween 20

    TGF-Î±

    transforming growth factor-alpha

    time-resolved fluorescence energy transfer

      Cohen, S. Isolation of a mouse submaxillary gland protein accelerating incisor eruption and eyelid opening in the new-born animal. J. Biol. Chem. 1962, 237, 1555â 1562, Â DOI: 10.1016/S0021-9258(19)83739-0
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      1
      Isolation of a mouse submaxillary gland protein accelerating incisor eruption and eyelid opening in the new-born animal
      Cohen, Stanley
      Journal of Biological Chemistry (1962), 237 (), 1555-62CODEN: JBCHA3; ISSN:0021-9258.
      A heat-stable protein has been isolated from the male mouse submaxillary gland which, upon injection, elicits precocious tooth eruption and eyelid sepn. in the new-born mouse and rat. The prepn. appears homogeneous when examd. by paper electrophoresis, paper chromatography, and immunoelectrophoresis. Only one component with a sedimentation constant of 1.25 S may be detected in the ultracentrifuge. The protein has an isoelec. point at pH 4.2. The amino acid analysis of the protein shows that lysine and phenylalanine are absent. All of the other common amino acids are present. The min. mol. wt., estd. from the assumed no. of amino acid residues, is â¼15,000. The biol. activity of the isolated tooth-lid factor is destroyed by incubation with chymotrypsin or a cryst. bacterial proteinase, and it is partially inactivated by trypsin. The factor is antigenic and may be pptd. with the aid of a specific rabbit antiserum.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaF3sXktFCj&md5=4736428b8a35ee370334e1993ee06bc1
    2. 2
      Cohen, S.; Levi-Montalcini, R. A nerve growth-stimulating factor isolated from snake venom. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. 1956, 42, 571â 574, Â DOI: 10.1073/pnas.42.9.571
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      2
      A nerve-growth-stimulating factor isolated from snake venom
      Cohen, Stanley; Levi-Montalcini, Rita
      Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (1956), 42 (), 571-4CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424.
      Results are presented of a partial purification and characterization of a nerve-growth-stimulating factor isolated from dried moccasin (Agkistrodon piscivorus) and rattlesnake (Crotalus adamanteus) venom. The active nondialyzable component was inactivated by heat, alkali, and anti-snake-venom serum. The biol. effects of the venom factor are similar to a factor obtained from sarcoma 180. The active material is a protein or is bound to a protein. A 20-fold purification was made in the following manner: 1 g. of venom and 36 g. of urea were dissolved in 80 ml. H2O contg. 3 ml. 0.1N NaOH. The soln. was allowed to stand at 0Â° for 90 min. All subsequent procedures were at 0Â°-3Â°. Satd. (NH4)2SO4 (pH 7.6 at 0Â°) was added to a final concn. of 48% satn. After 15 min. the mixt. was centrifuged for 5 min. at 16,000 g. The ppt. was discarded. (NH4)2SO4 was added to the supernatant fluid to a final concn. of 71% satn. After 15 min. the mixt. was centrifuged, the supernatant fluid discarded, and the ppt. dissolved in 40 ml. H2O, dialyzed against distd. H2O overnight, and then centrifuged for 10 min. at 16,000 g and the slight ppt. discarded. The supernatant fluid was again fractionated with satd. (NH4)2SO4 soln. The active material pptd. between 46 and 59% satn. After centrifugation, ppt. was dissolved in 20 ml. H2O and dialyzed overnight against distd. H2O. Ten ml. of the (NH4)2SO4 fraction (contg. 3.3 mg. protein/ml.) was passed through a column 1.4 cm. in diam. contg. 500 mg. DEAE-SF resins (1.1 meq./g.) at a flow rate of 0.1-0.2 ml./min. The column was then washed with 10 ml. of distd. H2O. The active material was eluted with 20 ml. of 0.01M NaCl in 0.01M K2HPO4 buffer, pH 7.4. This DEAE fraction contg. 15 mg. protein and 75% of the biol. activity was dialyzed with stirring for 5 hrs. against distd. H2O. Ten ml. (contg. 7 mg. of protein) were applied to a column 1.4 cm. in diam. contg. 500 mg. CM-cellulose (0.5 meq./g.) at a flow rate of 0.1-0.2 ml./min. After washing the column with 10 ml. H2O, 75% of the activity and 1.9 mg. protein was eluted with 10 ml. of 0.1M NaCl in 0.01M K2HPO4 buffer, pH 7.4.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaG2sXhslKjsQ%253D%253D&md5=dd4b93506e0017831ca8c67fa02caf54

      Cohen, S. Purification of a nerve-growth promoting protein from the mouse salivary gland and its neuro-cytotoxic antiserum. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1960, 46, 302, Â DOI: 10.1073/pnas.46.3.302
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      3
      Purification of a nerve-growth promoting protein from the mouse salivary gland and its neurocytotoxic antiserum
      Cohen, Stanley
      Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (1960), 46 (), 302-11CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424.
      The submaxillary glands excised from adult male mice were homogenized and treated with alc., (NH4)2SO4, and passed through various cellulose mixts. to obtain a 10-20% yield of pure nerve-growth factor. This factor was nondialyzable, heat- and acid-labile, had an ultraviolet absorption peak at 279 mÎ¼, and only 1 peak after ultracentrifugation, with a sedimentation const. of 4.33S. Injected into mice, the factor produced increases in protein and nucleic acid content in the sympathetic chain ganglia. A prepd. rabbit antiserum inhibited the effect of the factor in tissue culture and had specific neurocytotoxic activity in some mammals.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaF3cXmvVeqsw%253D%253D&md5=ccc3b3dc0f9a5756abecec1d872828a9

      Singh, A. B.; Harris, R. C. Autocrine, paracrine and juxtacrine signaling by EGFR ligands. Cell. Signal. 2005, 17, 1183â 1193, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.cellsig.2005.03.026
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      4
      Autocrine, paracrine and juxtacrine signaling by EGFR ligands
      Singh, Amar B.; Harris, Raymond C.
      Cellular Signalling (2005), 17 (10), 1183-1193CODEN: CESIEY; ISSN:0898-6568. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A review. Receptor and cytoplasmic protein tyrosine kinases play prominent roles in the control of a range of cellular processes during embryonic development and in the regulation of many metabolic and physiol. processes in a variety of tissues and organs. The epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) is a well-known and versatile signal transducer that has been highly conserved during evolution. It functions in a wide range of cellular processes, including cell fate detn., proliferation, cell migration and apoptosis. The no. of ligands that can activate the EGF receptor has increased during evolution. These ligands are synthesized as membrane-anchored precursor forms that are later shed by metalloproteinase-dependent cleavage to generate sol. ligands. In certain circumstances the membrane anchored isoforms as well as sol. growth factors may also act as biol. active ligands; therefore depending on the circumstances these ligands may induce juxtacrine, autocrine, paracrine and/or endocrine signaling. In this review, we discuss the different ways that EGFR ligands can activate the receptor and the possible biol. implications.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXmsVOns70%253D&md5=5d8f9d00d156b46ac2b342b3ed12c856

      Carpenter, G.; Cohen, S. 125I-labeled human epidermal growth factor. Binding, internalization, and degradation in human fibroblasts. J. Cell Biol. 1976, 71, 159â 171, Â DOI: 10.1083/jcb.71.1.159
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      5
      Iodine-125-labeled human epidermal growth factor. Binding, internalization, and degradation in human fibroblasts
      Carpenter, Graham; Cohen, Stanley
      Journal of Cell Biology (1976), 71 (1), 159-71CODEN: JCLBA3; ISSN:0021-9525.
      125I-labeled human epidermal growth factor (hEGF) bound in a specific and saturable manner to human fibroblasts. At 37Â°, the cell-bound 125I-hEGF initially was recovered in a native form by acid extn.; upon subsequent incubation, the cell-bound 125I-hEGF was degraded very rapidly, with the appearance in the medium of 125I-labeled monoiodotyrosine [70-78-0]. At 0Â°, cell-bound 125I-hEGF was not degraded but slowly dissocd. from the cell. The degrdn. was blocked by inhibitors of metabolic energy prodn. (azide, cyanide, dinitrophenol), some protease inhibitors (Tos-Lys-CH2Cl, benzyl guanidobenzoate), a lysosomotropic agent (chloroquine), various local anesthetics (cocaine, lidocaine, procaine), and ammonium chloride. After the binding and degrdn. of 125I-hEGF, the fibroblasts were no longer able to rebind fresh hormone. The binding capacity of these cells was restored by incubation in a serum-contg. medium; this restoration was inhibited by cycloheximide or actinomycin D.

      8
      Epidermal growth factor stimulates phosphorylation in membrane preparations in vitro
      Carpenter, Graham; King, Lloyd, Jr.; Cohen, Stanley
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (1978), 276 (5686), 409-10CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836.
      Addn. of epidermal growth factor (I) [62229-50-9] (40 ng) to a membrane prepn. from human epidermoid carcinoma A-431 cells produced a 3-4-fold stimulation of the phosphorylation of endogenous membrane proteins at 0Â° in the presence of ATP; the initial rate of phosphorylation was increased from 16.7 to 50 pmol phosphate incorporated/min/mg of protein. Max. stimulation of membrane protein phosphorylation occurred in the presence of 3 Ã 10-8M I. Both the endogenous membrane and the I-stimulated phosphorylation required Mg2+ or Mn2+ and both reactions were heat-sensitive. The I-stimulated membrane protein kinase activity could phosphorylate exogenous as well as endogenous proteins. During the 1st minute of incubation with I, membrane components with mol. wts. of â¼170,000 and â¼150,000 were heavily phosphorylated; with continued incubation, addnl. membrane components were phosphorylated to a greater extent, particularly those with apparent mol. wts. of 80,000 and 22,500. Thus, these data show the modulation of a biochem. reaction in a cell-free membrane prepn. as a result of the formation of I-receptor complexes.

      9
      Epidermal growth factor-receptor-protein kinase interactions. Co-purification of receptor and epidermal growth factor-enhanced phosphorylation activity
      Cohen, Stanley; Carpenter, Graham; King, Lloyd, Jr.
      Journal of Biological Chemistry (1980), 255 (10), 4834-42CODEN: JBCHA3; ISSN:0021-9258.
      Membranes prepd. from A-431 human epidermoid carcinoma cells bound 125I-labeled epidermal growth factor (EGF) [62229-50-9] in a specific manner and, in the presence of EGF, catalyzed the phosphorylation of a no. of endogenous membrane proteins. The activation of the membrane-assocd. protein kinase [9026-43-1] by EGF was apparently reversible. The membrane prepn. was solubilized by a no. of nonionic detergents with the retention of both 125I-labeled EGF-binding activity and EGF-enhanced phosphorylation of specific membrane proteins. The solubilized membrane prepn. was purified by affinity chromatog. using EGF covalently, linked to Affi-Gel. The purified prepn. retained both EGF-binding activity and EGF-enhanced phosphorylation activity. Anal. of the affinity-purified prepn. by sodium dodecyl sulfate-gel electrophoresis indicated the presence of 1 major protein band of mol. wt. 150,000 and several trace bands. The major 150,000 protein band is the receptor for EGF and is a substrate of the phosphorylation reaction. The co-purifn. of EGF-binding activity and EGF-stimulated phosphorylation activity suggests an inherent close relation.

      10
      Epithelial immaturity and multiorgan failure in mice lacking epidermal growth factor receptor
      Miettinen, Paivi J.; Berger, Joel E.; Meneses, Juanito; Phung, Yume; Pedersen, Roger A.; Werb, Zena; Derynck, Rik
      Nature (London) (1995), 376 (6538), 337-41CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Macmillan Magazines)
      Since the discovery that epidermal growth factor (EGF) can accelerate opening of the eyelids, the EGF receptor (EGF-R) has been extensively studied and is now considered to be a prototype tyrosine kinase receptor. Binding of EGF or of transforming growth factor-Î± (TGF-Î±) or other related factors activates the receptor and induces cell proliferation and differentiation. Although it is not found on hematopoietic cells, the EGF-R is widely expressed in mammals and has been implicated in various stages of embryonic development. Here the developmental and physiol. roles of this receptor and its ligands were investigated by inactivating the gene encoding EGF-R. It was found that EGF-R-/- mice survive for up to 8 days after birth and suffer from impaired epithelial development in several organs, including skin, lung and gastrointestinal tract.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2MXnt1Sjs70%253D&md5=eb086c177670b4ac7f6b09e615623f83

      11
      Epidermal growth factor and the multiplication of cultured human epidermal keratinocytes
      Rheinwald J G; Green H
      Nature (1977), 265 (5593), 421-4 ISSN:0028-0836.
      The culture lifetime of epidermal cells of newborn humans is increased from 50 to 150 generations by adding to the medium epidermal growth factor, a polypeptide mitogen. EGF seems to delay senescence of the cells by maintaining them in a state further removed from terminal differentiation. This effect is revealed by a greater ability of the cells to survive subculture and initiate new colonies, but not necessarily by an increased growth rate.

      De Larco, J. E.; Todaro, G. J. Growth factors from murine sarcoma virus-transformed cells. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1978, 75, 4001, Â DOI: 10.1073/pnas.75.8.4001
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      14
      Growth factors from murine sarcoma virus-transformed cells
      De Larco, Joseph E.; Todaro, George J.
      Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (1978), 75 (8), 4001-5CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424.
      Murine sarcoma virus-transformed mouse fibroblasts produced polypeptide growth factors and released them into serum-free medium. These factors stimulated cells to divide in monolayer cultures and also to form colonies that grew progressively in soft agar. Three major peaks of activity were seen, with apparent mol. wts. of 25,000, 12,000, and 7000. The sarcoma growth factors were heat-stable, trypsin-sensitive, and active in ng quantities when tested for growth stimulation of untransformed rat and mouse fibroblasts. All three mol. species were capable of competing for membrane epidermal growth factor (EGF) receptors when tested with 125I-labeled EGF. They differed from mouse EGF in their mol. wts., in their inability to react with anti-EGF antibodies, and in their ability to convert cells to anchorage independent (agar) growth. For the above reasons, it was concluded that the sarcoma growth factors are a new class of polypeptide tropic factors that confer on fibroblasts in vitro properties assocd. with the transformed phenotype.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaE1cXls1Whs7s%253D&md5=064e6cda6baeb79ec646382317e7e7bb

      Higashiyama, S.; Abraham, J. A.; Miller, J.; Fiddes, J. C.; Klagsbrun, M. A heparin-binding growth factor secreted by macrophage-like cells that is related to EGF. Science 1991, 251, 936â 939, Â DOI: 10.1126/science.1840698
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      15
      A heparin-binding growth factor secreted by macrophage-like cells that is related to EGF
      Higashiyama, Shigeki; Abraham, Judith A.; Miller, Judy; Fiddes, John C.; Klagsbrun, Michael
      Science (Washington, DC, United States) (1991), 251 (4996), 936-9CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075.
      Macrophage-like U-937 cells secrete a 22-kilodalton heparin-binding growth factor that is mitogenic for BALB-3T3 fibroblasts and smooth muscle cells, but not endothelial cells. The amino acid sequence predicted from cDNA clones indicates that the mitogen is a new member of the epidermal growth factor (EGF) family. This heparin-binding EGF-like growth factor (HB-EGF) binds to EGF receptors on A-431 epidermoid carcinoma cells and smooth muscle cells, but is a far more potent mitogen for smooth muscle cells than is EGF. HB-EGF is also expressed in cultured human macrophages and may be involved in macrophage-mediated cellular proliferation.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®

      16
      Betacellulin: a mitogen from pancreatic Î² cell tumors
      Shing, Y.; Christofori, G.; Hanahan, D.; Ono, Y.; Sasada, R.; Igarashi, K.; Folkman, J.
      Science (Washington, DC, United States) (1993), 259 (5101), 1604-7CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075.
      Betacellulin, a member of the epidermal growth factor family, has been identified in the conditioned medium of cell lines derived from mouse pancreatic Î² cell tumors. Betacellulin is a 32-kilodalton glycoprotein that appears to be processed from a larger transmembrane precursor by proteolytic cleavage. The carboxyl-terminal domain of betacellulin has 50 percent sequence similarity with that of rat transforming growth factor Î±. Betacellulin is a potent mitogen for retinal pigment epithelial cells and vascular smooth muscle cells.

      17
      Structure and function of human amphiregulin: a member of the epidermal growth factor family
      Shoyab, Mohammed; Plowman, Gregory D.; McDonald, Vicki L.; Bradley, J. Garrett; Todaro, George J.
      Science (Washington, DC, United States) (1989), 243 (4894, Pt. 1), 1074-6CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075.
      The complete amino acid sequence of amphiregulin, a bifunctional cell growth modulator, was detd. The truncated form contains 78 amino acids, whereas a larger form of amphiregulin contains 6 addnl. amino acids at the amino-terminal end. The amino-terminal half of amphiregulin is extremely hydrophilic and contains unusually high nos. of lysine, arginine, and asparagine residues. The carboxyl-terminal half of amphiregulin (residues 46 to 84) exhibits striking homol. to the EGF family of proteins. Amphiregulin binds to the EGF receptor but not as well as EGF does. Amphiregulin fully supplants the requirement for EGF or transforming growth factor-Î± in murine keratinocyte growth, but it is a much weaker growth stimulator in other cell systems.

      18
      Amphiregulin: a bifunctional growth-modulating glycoprotein produced by the phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate-treated human breast adenocarcinoma cell line MCF-7
      Shoyab, Mohammed; McDonald, Vicki L.; Bradley, J. Garrett; Todaro, George J.
      Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (1988), 85 (17), 6528-32CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424.
      A glycoprotein, termed amphiregulin (AR), inhibits the growth of several human carcinoma cells in culture and stimulates proliferation of human fibroblasts and certain other tumor cells. It has been purified to apparent homogeneity from serum-free conditioned medium of MCF-7 human breast carcinoma cells that had been treated with phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate. AR is a single-chain extremely hydrophilic glycoprotein contg. cysteines in disulfide linkage(s) that are essential for biol. activity; it is stable between pH 2 and pH 12 and after heating for 30 min at 56Â° but unstable at 100Â°. The apparent mol. wts. of AR and N-glycanase-treated AR are 14,000 and 15,000, resp., as assessed by gel chromatog., and â22,500 and â14,000, resp., as detd. by PAGE. Treatment of AR with N-glycanase, O-glycanase, or neuraminidase does not affect its activity. The pI of AR is â7.8. The amino-terminal amino acid sequence of AR has been detd., and no significant sequence homol. between AR and other proteins was found. The mol. thus appears to be a distinct growth regulatory protein.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®

      Toyoda, H.; Komurasaki, T.; Uchida, D.; Takayama, Y.; Isobe, T.; Okuyama, T.; Hanada, K. Epiregulin a novel epidermal growth factor with mitogenic activity for rat primary hepatocytes. J. Biol. Chem. 1995, 270, 7495â 7500, Â DOI: 10.1074/jbc.270.13.7495
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      19
      A novel epidermal growth factor with mitogenic activity for rat primary hepatocytes
      Toyoda, Hitoshi; Komurasaki, Toshi; Uchida, Daisuke; Takayama, Yasuko; Isobe, Toshiaki; Okuyama, Tuneo; Hanada, Kazunori
      Journal of Biological Chemistry (1995), 270 (13), 7495-500CODEN: JBCHA3; ISSN:0021-9258. (American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology)
      Epiregulin, a novel epidermal growth factor (EGF)-related growth regulating peptide, was purified from conditioned medium of the mouse fibroblast-derived tumor cell line NIH3T3/clone T7. It was a 46-amino-acid single chain polypeptide, and its amino acid sequence exhibited 24-50% amino acid sequence identity with sequences of other EGF-related growth factors. Epiregulin exhibited bifunctional regulatory properties: it inhibited the growth of several epithelial tumor cells and stimulated the growth of fibroblasts and various other types of cells. Epiregulin bound to the EGF receptors of epidermoid carcinoma A431 cells much more weakly than did EGF, but was nevertheless much more potent than EGF as a mitogen for rat primary hepatocytes and Balb/c 3T3 A31 fibroblasts. These findings suggest that epiregulin plays important roles in regulating the growth of epithelial cells and fibroblasts by binding to receptors for EGF-related ligands.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2MXkvVOjsLc%253D&md5=f3af4fc255d95fd6cd9a2faf9140da66

      Strachan, L.; Murison, J. G.; Prestidge, R. L.; Sleeman, M. A.; Watson, J. D.; Kumble, K. D. Cloning and biological activity of epigen, a novel member of the epidermal growth factor superfamily. J. Biol. Chem. 2001, 276, 18265â 18271, Â DOI: 10.1074/jbc.M006935200
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      20
      Cloning and biological activity of Epigen, a novel member of the epidermal growth factor superfamily
      Strachan, Lorna; Murison, J. Greg; Prestidge, Ross L.; Sleeman, Matthew A.; Watson, James D.; Kumble, Krishnanand D.
      Journal of Biological Chemistry (2001), 276 (21), 18265-18271CODEN: JBCHA3; ISSN:0021-9258. (American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology)
      High throughput sequencing of a mouse keratinocyte library was used to identify an expressed sequence tag with homol. to the epidermal growth factor (EGF) family of growth factors. The authors have named the protein encoded by this expressed sequence tag Epigen, for epithelial mitogen. Epigen encodes a protein of 152 amino acids that contains features characteristic of the EGF superfamily. Two hydrophobic regions, corresponding to a putative signal sequence and transmembrane domain, flank a core of amino acids encompassing six cysteine residues and two putative N-linked glycosylation sites. Epigen shows 24-37% identity to members of the EGF superfamily including EGF, transforming growth factor Î±, and Epiregulin. Northern blotting of several adult mouse tissues indicated that Epigen was present in testis, heart, and liver. Recombinant Epigen was synthesized in Escherichia coli and refolded, and its biol. activity was compared with that of EGF and transforming growth factor Î± in several assays. In epithelial cells, Epigen stimulated the phosphorylation of c-erbB-1 and mitogen-activated protein kinases and also activated a reporter gene contg. enhancer sequences present in the c-fos promoter. Epigen also stimulated the proliferation of HaCaT cells, and this proliferation was blocked by an antibody to the extracellular domain of the receptor tyrosine kinase c-erbB-1. Thus, Epigen is the newest member of the EGF superfamily and, with its ability to promote the growth of epithelial cells, may constitute a novel mol. target for wound-healing therapy.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXktFWmtr4%253D&md5=303932b3fc2f119947e0a15c1ce9ca5f

      The genome of Shope fibroma virus, a tumorigenic poxvirus, contains a growth factor gene with sequence similarity to those encoding epidermal growth factor and transforming growth factor alpha

      Molecular and Cellular Biology (1987), 7 (1), 535-40CODEN: MCEBD4; ISSN:0270-7306.
      Degenerate oligonucleotide probes corresponding to a highly conserved region common to epidermal growth factor, transforming growth factor alpha, and vaccinia growth factor were used to identify a novel growth factor gene in the Shope fibroma virus genome. Sequence anal. indicates that the Shope fibroma growth factor is a distinct new member of this family of growth factors.

      The gene lin-3 encodes an inductive signal for vulval development in C. elegans
      Hill, Russell J.; Sternberg, Paul W.
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (1992), 358 (6386), 470-6CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836.
      The lin-3 gene is necessary for induction of the Caenorhabditis elegans vulva by the anchor cell. It encodes a mol. similar to epidermal growth factor and to transforming growth factor-Î± and acts through the epidermal growth factor receptor homolog let-23. Expression of lin-3 in the anchor cell stimulates vulval induction; lin-3 may encode the vulval inducing signal.

      The Drosophila spitz gene encodes a putative EGF-like growth factor involved in dorsal-ventral axis formation and neurogenesis
      Rutledge, Barbara J.; Zhang, Kang; Bier, Ethan; Jan, Yuh Nung; Perrimon, Norbert
      Genes & Development (1992), 6 (8), 1503-17CODEN: GEDEEP; ISSN:0890-9369.
      The mol. characterization of the Drosophila melanogaster gene spitz (spi), which encodes a putative 26-kDa, EGF-like transmembrane protein that is structurally similar to TGF-Î±, is described. Temporal and spatial expression patterns of spi transcripts indicate that spi is expressed throughout the embryo. Examn. of mutant embryos reveals that spi is involved in a no. of unrelated developmental choices, for example, dorsal-ventral axis formation, glial migration, sensory organ detn., and muscle development. Thus, spi may act as a ligand for cell-specific receptors, possibly rhomboid and/or the Drosophila EGF receptor homolog.

      Shope fibroma virus growth factor exhibits epidermal growth factor activities in newborn mice
      Ye, Yuang Kang; Lin, Yao Zhong; Tam, James P.
      Biochemical and Biophysical Research Communications (1988), 154 (2), 497-501CODEN: BBRCA9; ISSN:0006-291X.
      A synthetic 55-residue peptide consisting of the C portion of the predicted genomic DNA sequence of Shope fibroma virus growth factor (SFGF residue 26-80) exhibited EGF-transforming growth factor activities in newborn mice. The synthetic SFGF accelerated precocious incisor eruption and eyelid opening in newborn mice and also retarded the overall growth rates of hair, body wt., and body length when administered in dosages of 4-6 Î¼g/g body wt. The results of whole animal studies indicate that SFGF belongs to the EGF-TGFÎ± family and exerts similar biol. effects in newborn animals.

      Bui, T. Q.; Bui, Q. V. P.; NÃ©meth, D.; Hegyi, P.; SzakÃ¡cs, Z.; Rumbus, Z.; TÃ³th, B.; Emri, G.; PÃ¡rniczky, A.; SarlÃ³s, P. Epidermal growth factor is effective in the treatment of diabetic foot ulcers: meta-analysis and systematic review. Int. J. Environ. Res. 2019, 16, 2584, Â DOI: 10.3390/ijerph16142584
      [Crossref], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      25
      Epidermal growth factor is e effective in the treatment of diabetic foot ulcers: meta-analysis and systematic review
      Bui, Thien Quoc; Van Phu Bui, Quoc; Nemeth, David; Hegyi, Peter; Szakacs, Zsolt; Rumbus, Zoltan; Toth, Barbara; Emri, Gabriella; Parniczky, Andrea; Sarlos, Patricia; Varga, Orsolya
      International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health (2019), 16 (14), 2584CODEN: IJERGQ; ISSN:1660-4601. (MDPI AG)
      A review. Diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs) are one the common complications of diabetes mellitus. Many trials were performed to evaluate the effect of recombinant human epidermal growth factor (rhEGF) in healing DFUs. This meta-anal. was performed to synthesize the evidence of rhEGF treatment in DFUs in comparison to placebo. Databases included for the search were PubMed, EMBASE, the Cochrane Library, Web of Science, EBSCOhost, ScienceDirect, and Scopus (up to Jan. 2019). The outcome of interest was the complete healing rate of DFUs. We performed random effects meta-anal. stratified by the types of administration route (intralesional injection and topical apply) by calcg. the odds ratios (OR) and 95% confidence interval (95% CI). A total of six studies involving 530 patients were eligible for anal. The combined OR (intralesional injection and topical apply) was 4.005 (95% CI: (2.248; 7.135), p < 0.001). The ORs for intralesional injection and topical application were 3.599 (95% CI: (1.213; 10.677), p = 0.021) and 4.176 (95% CI: (2.112; 8.256), p < 0.001), resp. Statistical heterogeneity might not be important in overall treatment (I2 = 15.17, p = 0.317) and both of the subgroups (I2: 24.56, p = 0.25 and I2: 33.26, p = 0.213, resp.). Our results support the use of rhEGF in the treatment of DFUs.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXisVCmurvF&md5=4eb9cf8ceee00cb9471f623ac6c2fdb8
