      Polymorphonuclear leukocytes-mediated lysis of A431 cells induced by IgG1 mouse anti-epidermal growth factor receptor monoclonal antibodies
      Kawamoto, Tomoyuki; Kishimoto, Kouji; Takahashi, Kojiro; Matsumura, Tomohiro; Sato, J. Denry; Taniguchi, Shigehiko
      In Vitro Cellular & Developmental Biology: Animal (1992), 28A (11-12), 782-6CODEN: IVCAED; ISSN:0883-8364.
      The ability of different Fc receptors (FcÎ³R) on IgG-mediated cytotoxicity for human epidermoid carcinoma A431 cells bearing large no. of epidermal growth factor receptors (EGFRs) was examd. by using two isotypes (IgG1 and IgG2a) of murine monoclonal antibodies (MoAbs) against EGFR in the presence of human monocytes and granulocytes. Two MoAbs (225 and LA1) of the IgG1 isotype exhibited effective cytolytic activity for A431 cells with human polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMN) rather than with human mononuclear cells (MNC). In contrast, two MoAbs (528 and 579) of the IgG2a-isotype lysed the cells less effectively with PMN than with MNC. Anti-FcÎ³RII (CDw32) MoAb 2E1 inhibited the IgG1-mediated cytotoxicity by PMN, and anti-FcÎ³RIII (CD16) MoAb 80H3 did not inhibit the IgG2a-mediated cytotoxicity by MNC. Under these conditions, antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity by mouse MoAb IgG1 isotypes resulted from antibody binding to the FcÎ³RII (CDw32) of PMN.

      Levitzki, A.; Gazit, A. Tyrosine kinase inhibition: an approach to drug development. Science 1995, 267, 1782â 1788, Â DOI: 10.1126/science.7892601

      Tyrosine kinase inhibition: an approach to drug development
      Levitzki, Alexander; Gazit, Aviv
      Science (Washington, D. C.) (1995), 267 (5205), 1782-8CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      Protein tyrosine kinases (PTKs) regulate cell proliferation, cell differentiation, and signaling processes in the cells of the immune system. Uncontrolled signaling from receptor tyrosine kinases and intracellular tyrosine kinases can lead to inflammatory responses and to diseases such as cancer, atherosclerosis, and psoriasis. Thus, inhibitors that block the activity of tyrosine kinases and the signaling pathways they activate may provide a useful basis for drug development. This article summarizes recent progress in the development of PTK inhibitors and demonstrates their potential use in the treatment of disease.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2MXkslWgtL4%253D&md5=9483020dfd9d97f022029178a1c2de77
    80. 80
      Favata, M. F.; Horiuchi, K. Y.; Manos, E. J.; Daulerio, A. J.; Stradley, D. A.; Feeser, W. S.; Van Dyk, D. E.; Pitts, W. J.; Earl, R. A.; Hobbs, F. Identification of a novel inhibitor of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase. J. Biol. Chem. 1998, 273, 18623â 18632, Â DOI: 10.1074/jbc.273.29.18623
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      80
      Identification of a novel inhibitor of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase
      Favata, Margaret F.; Horiuchi, Kurumi Y.; Manos, Elizabeth J.; Daulerio, Andrea J.; Stradley, Deborah A.; Feeser, Wendi S.; Van Dyk, Drew E.; Pitts, William J.; Earl, Richard A.; Hobbs, Frank; Copeland, Robert A.; Magolda, Ronald L.; Scherle, Peggy A.; Trzaskos, James M.
      Journal of Biological Chemistry (1998), 273 (29), 18623-18632CODEN: JBCHA3; ISSN:0021-9258. (American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology)
      The compd. U0126 (1,4-diamino-2,3-dicyano-1,4-bis[2-aminophenylthio]butadiene) was identified as an inhibitor of AP-1 transactivation in a cell-based reporter assay. U0126 was also shown to inhibit endogenous promoters contg. AP-1 response elements but did not affect genes lacking an AP-1 response element in their promoters. These effects of U0126 result from direct inhibition of the mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase family members, MEK-1 and MEK-2. Inhibition is selective for MEK-1 and -2, as U0126 shows little, if any, effect on the kinase activities of protein kinase C, Abl, Raf, MEKK, ERK, JNK, MKK-3, MKK-4/SEK, MKK-6, Cdk2, or Cdk4. Comparative kinetic anal. of U0126 and the MEK inhibitor PD098059 (Dudley, D. T., Pang, L., Decker, S. J., Bridges, A. J., and Saltiel, A. R. (1995) Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci U. S. A. 92, 7686-7689) demonstrates that U0126 and PD098059 are noncompetitive inhibitors with respect to both MEK substrates, ATP and ERK. We further demonstrate that the two compds. bind to ÎN3-S218E/S222D MEK in a mutually exclusive fashion, suggesting that they may share a common or overlapping binding site(s). Quant. evaluation of the steady state kinetics of MEK inhibition by these compds. reveals that U0126 has approx. 100-fold higher affinity for ÎN3-S218E/S222D MEK than does PD098059. We further tested the effects of these compds. on the activity of wild type MEK isolated after activation from stimulated cells. Surprisingly, we observe a significant diminution in affinity of both compds. for wild type MEK as compared with the ÎN3-S218E/S222D mutant enzyme. These results suggest that the affinity of both compds. is mediated by subtle conformational differences between the two activated MEK forms. The MEK affinity of U0126, its selectivity for MEK over other kinases, and its cellular efficacy suggest that this compd. will serve as a powerful tool for in vitro and cellular investigations of mitogen-activated protein kinase-mediated signal transduction.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®

        Cohen, S. Isolation of a mouse submaxillary gland protein accelerating incisor eruption and eyelid opening in the new-born animal. J. Biol. Chem. 1962, 237, 1555â 1562, Â DOI: 10.1016/S0021-9258(19)83739-0
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        1
        Isolation of a mouse submaxillary gland protein accelerating incisor eruption and eyelid opening in the new-born animal
        Cohen, Stanley
        Journal of Biological Chemistry (1962), 237 (), 1555-62CODEN: JBCHA3; ISSN:0021-9258.
        A heat-stable protein has been isolated from the male mouse submaxillary gland which, upon injection, elicits precocious tooth eruption and eyelid sepn. in the new-born mouse and rat. The prepn. appears homogeneous when examd. by paper electrophoresis, paper chromatography, and immunoelectrophoresis. Only one component with a sedimentation constant of 1.25 S may be detected in the ultracentrifuge. The protein has an isoelec. point at pH 4.2. The amino acid analysis of the protein shows that lysine and phenylalanine are absent. All of the other common amino acids are present. The min. mol. wt., estd. from the assumed no. of amino acid residues, is â¼15,000. The biol. activity of the isolated tooth-lid factor is destroyed by incubation with chymotrypsin or a cryst. bacterial proteinase, and it is partially inactivated by trypsin. The factor is antigenic and may be pptd. with the aid of a specific rabbit antiserum.

        Cohen, S.; Levi-Montalcini, R. A nerve growth-stimulating factor isolated from snake venom. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. 1956, 42, 571â 574, Â DOI: 10.1073/pnas.42.9.571
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        2
        A nerve-growth-stimulating factor isolated from snake venom
        Cohen, Stanley; Levi-Montalcini, Rita
        Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (1956), 42 (), 571-4CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424.
        Results are presented of a partial purification and characterization of a nerve-growth-stimulating factor isolated from dried moccasin (Agkistrodon piscivorus) and rattlesnake (Crotalus adamanteus) venom. The active nondialyzable component was inactivated by heat, alkali, and anti-snake-venom serum. The biol. effects of the venom factor are similar to a factor obtained from sarcoma 180. The active material is a protein or is bound to a protein. A 20-fold purification was made in the following manner: 1 g. of venom and 36 g. of urea were dissolved in 80 ml. H2O contg. 3 ml. 0.1N NaOH. The soln. was allowed to stand at 0Â° for 90 min. All subsequent procedures were at 0Â°-3Â°. Satd. (NH4)2SO4 (pH 7.6 at 0Â°) was added to a final concn. of 48% satn. After 15 min. the mixt. was centrifuged for 5 min. at 16,000 g. The ppt. was discarded. (NH4)2SO4 was added to the supernatant fluid to a final concn. of 71% satn. After 15 min. the mixt. was centrifuged, the supernatant fluid discarded, and the ppt. dissolved in 40 ml. H2O, dialyzed against distd. H2O overnight, and then centrifuged for 10 min. at 16,000 g and the slight ppt. discarded. The supernatant fluid was again fractionated with satd. (NH4)2SO4 soln. The active material pptd. between 46 and 59% satn. After centrifugation, ppt. was dissolved in 20 ml. H2O and dialyzed overnight against distd. H2O. Ten ml. of the (NH4)2SO4 fraction (contg. 3.3 mg. protein/ml.) was passed through a column 1.4 cm. in diam. contg. 500 mg. DEAE-SF resins (1.1 meq./g.) at a flow rate of 0.1-0.2 ml./min. The column was then washed with 10 ml. of distd. H2O. The active material was eluted with 20 ml. of 0.01M NaCl in 0.01M K2HPO4 buffer, pH 7.4. This DEAE fraction contg. 15 mg. protein and 75% of the biol. activity was dialyzed with stirring for 5 hrs. against distd. H2O. Ten ml. (contg. 7 mg. of protein) were applied to a column 1.4 cm. in diam. contg. 500 mg. CM-cellulose (0.5 meq./g.) at a flow rate of 0.1-0.2 ml./min. After washing the column with 10 ml. H2O, 75% of the activity and 1.9 mg. protein was eluted with 10 ml. of 0.1M NaCl in 0.01M K2HPO4 buffer, pH 7.4.

        Cohen, S. Purification of a nerve-growth promoting protein from the mouse salivary gland and its neuro-cytotoxic antiserum. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1960, 46, 302, Â DOI: 10.1073/pnas.46.3.302

        Purification of a nerve-growth promoting protein from the mouse salivary gland and its neurocytotoxic antiserum
        Cohen, Stanley
        Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (1960), 46 (), 302-11CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424.
        The submaxillary glands excised from adult male mice were homogenized and treated with alc., (NH4)2SO4, and passed through various cellulose mixts. to obtain a 10-20% yield of pure nerve-growth factor. This factor was nondialyzable, heat- and acid-labile, had an ultraviolet absorption peak at 279 mÎ¼, and only 1 peak after ultracentrifugation, with a sedimentation const. of 4.33S. Injected into mice, the factor produced increases in protein and nucleic acid content in the sympathetic chain ganglia. A prepd. rabbit antiserum inhibited the effect of the factor in tissue culture and had specific neurocytotoxic activity in some mammals.

        Singh, A. B.; Harris, R. C. Autocrine, paracrine and juxtacrine signaling by EGFR ligands. Cell. Signal. 2005, 17, 1183â 1193, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.cellsig.2005.03.026
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        4
        Autocrine, paracrine and juxtacrine signaling by EGFR ligands
        Singh, Amar B.; Harris, Raymond C.
        Cellular Signalling (2005), 17 (10), 1183-1193CODEN: CESIEY; ISSN:0898-6568. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A review. Receptor and cytoplasmic protein tyrosine kinases play prominent roles in the control of a range of cellular processes during embryonic development and in the regulation of many metabolic and physiol. processes in a variety of tissues and organs. The epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) is a well-known and versatile signal transducer that has been highly conserved during evolution. It functions in a wide range of cellular processes, including cell fate detn., proliferation, cell migration and apoptosis. The no. of ligands that can activate the EGF receptor has increased during evolution. These ligands are synthesized as membrane-anchored precursor forms that are later shed by metalloproteinase-dependent cleavage to generate sol. ligands. In certain circumstances the membrane anchored isoforms as well as sol. growth factors may also act as biol. active ligands; therefore depending on the circumstances these ligands may induce juxtacrine, autocrine, paracrine and/or endocrine signaling. In this review, we discuss the different ways that EGFR ligands can activate the receptor and the possible biol. implications.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXmsVOns70%253D&md5=5d8f9d00d156b46ac2b342b3ed12c856
      5. 5
        Carpenter, G.; Cohen, S. 125I-labeled human epidermal growth factor. Binding, internalization, and degradation in human fibroblasts. J. Cell Biol. 1976, 71, 159â 171, Â DOI: 10.1083/jcb.71.1.159
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        5
        Iodine-125-labeled human epidermal growth factor. Binding, internalization, and degradation in human fibroblasts
        Carpenter, Graham; Cohen, Stanley
        Journal of Cell Biology (1976), 71 (1), 159-71CODEN: JCLBA3; ISSN:0021-9525.
        125I-labeled human epidermal growth factor (hEGF) bound in a specific and saturable manner to human fibroblasts. At 37Â°, the cell-bound 125I-hEGF initially was recovered in a native form by acid extn.; upon subsequent incubation, the cell-bound 125I-hEGF was degraded very rapidly, with the appearance in the medium of 125I-labeled monoiodotyrosine [70-78-0]. At 0Â°, cell-bound 125I-hEGF was not degraded but slowly dissocd. from the cell. The degrdn. was blocked by inhibitors of metabolic energy prodn. (azide, cyanide, dinitrophenol), some protease inhibitors (Tos-Lys-CH2Cl, benzyl guanidobenzoate), a lysosomotropic agent (chloroquine), various local anesthetics (cocaine, lidocaine, procaine), and ammonium chloride. After the binding and degrdn. of 125I-hEGF, the fibroblasts were no longer able to rebind fresh hormone. The binding capacity of these cells was restored by incubation in a serum-contg. medium; this restoration was inhibited by cycloheximide or actinomycin D.

        Carpenter, G.; Lloyd, K., Jr.; Cohen, S. Epidermal growth factor stimulates phosphorylation in membrane preparations in vitro. Nature 1978, 276, 409, Â DOI: 10.1038/276409a0
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        8
        Epidermal growth factor stimulates phosphorylation in membrane preparations in vitro
        Carpenter, Graham; King, Lloyd, Jr.; Cohen, Stanley
        Nature (London, United Kingdom) (1978), 276 (5686), 409-10CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836.
        Addn. of epidermal growth factor (I) [62229-50-9] (40 ng) to a membrane prepn. from human epidermoid carcinoma A-431 cells produced a 3-4-fold stimulation of the phosphorylation of endogenous membrane proteins at 0Â° in the presence of ATP; the initial rate of phosphorylation was increased from 16.7 to 50 pmol phosphate incorporated/min/mg of protein. Max. stimulation of membrane protein phosphorylation occurred in the presence of 3 Ã 10-8M I. Both the endogenous membrane and the I-stimulated phosphorylation required Mg2+ or Mn2+ and both reactions were heat-sensitive. The I-stimulated membrane protein kinase activity could phosphorylate exogenous as well as endogenous proteins. During the 1st minute of incubation with I, membrane components with mol. wts. of â¼170,000 and â¼150,000 were heavily phosphorylated; with continued incubation, addnl. membrane components were phosphorylated to a greater extent, particularly those with apparent mol. wts. of 80,000 and 22,500. Thus, these data show the modulation of a biochem. reaction in a cell-free membrane prepn. as a result of the formation of I-receptor complexes.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaE1MXhs1agt74%253D&md5=2e59b28330ac064304c326157f2f107b
      9. 9
        Cohen, S.; Carpenter, G.; King, L. Epidermal growth factor-receptor-protein kinase interactions. Co-purification of receptor and epidermal growth factor-enhanced phosphorylation activity. J. Biol. Chem. 1980, 255, 4834â 4842, Â DOI: 10.1016/S0021-9258(19)85573-4
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        9
        Epidermal growth factor-receptor-protein kinase interactions. Co-purification of receptor and epidermal growth factor-enhanced phosphorylation activity
        Cohen, Stanley; Carpenter, Graham; King, Lloyd, Jr.
        Journal of Biological Chemistry (1980), 255 (10), 4834-42CODEN: JBCHA3; ISSN:0021-9258.
        Membranes prepd. from A-431 human epidermoid carcinoma cells bound 125I-labeled epidermal growth factor (EGF) [62229-50-9] in a specific manner and, in the presence of EGF, catalyzed the phosphorylation of a no. of endogenous membrane proteins. The activation of the membrane-assocd. protein kinase [9026-43-1] by EGF was apparently reversible. The membrane prepn. was solubilized by a no. of nonionic detergents with the retention of both 125I-labeled EGF-binding activity and EGF-enhanced phosphorylation of specific membrane proteins. The solubilized membrane prepn. was purified by affinity chromatog. using EGF covalently, linked to Affi-Gel. The purified prepn. retained both EGF-binding activity and EGF-enhanced phosphorylation activity. Anal. of the affinity-purified prepn. by sodium dodecyl sulfate-gel electrophoresis indicated the presence of 1 major protein band of mol. wt. 150,000 and several trace bands. The major 150,000 protein band is the receptor for EGF and is a substrate of the phosphorylation reaction. The co-purifn. of EGF-binding activity and EGF-stimulated phosphorylation activity suggests an inherent close relation.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL3cXks1WqsL4%253D&md5=72ecae703a0db126989d27abcd55f812
      10. 10
        Miettinen, P. J.; Berger, J. E.; Meneses, J.; Phung, Y.; Pedersen, R. A.; Werb, Z.; Derynck, R. Epithelial immaturity and multiorgan failure in mice lacking epidermal growth factor receptor. Nature 1995, 376, 337, Â DOI: 10.1038/376337a0
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        10
        Epithelial immaturity and multiorgan failure in mice lacking epidermal growth factor receptor
        Miettinen, Paivi J.; Berger, Joel E.; Meneses, Juanito; Phung, Yume; Pedersen, Roger A.; Werb, Zena; Derynck, Rik
        Nature (London) (1995), 376 (6538), 337-41CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Macmillan Magazines)
        Since the discovery that epidermal growth factor (EGF) can accelerate opening of the eyelids, the EGF receptor (EGF-R) has been extensively studied and is now considered to be a prototype tyrosine kinase receptor. Binding of EGF or of transforming growth factor-Î± (TGF-Î±) or other related factors activates the receptor and induces cell proliferation and differentiation. Although it is not found on hematopoietic cells, the EGF-R is widely expressed in mammals and has been implicated in various stages of embryonic development. Here the developmental and physiol. roles of this receptor and its ligands were investigated by inactivating the gene encoding EGF-R. It was found that EGF-R-/- mice survive for up to 8 days after birth and suffer from impaired epithelial development in several organs, including skin, lung and gastrointestinal tract.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2MXnt1Sjs70%253D&md5=eb086c177670b4ac7f6b09e615623f83
      11. 11
        Rheinwald, J. G.; Green, H. Epidermal growth factor and the multiplication of cultured human epidermal keratinocytes. Nature 1977, 265, 421, Â DOI: 10.1038/265421a0
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        11
        Epidermal growth factor and the multiplication of cultured human epidermal keratinocytes
        Rheinwald J G; Green H
        Nature (1977), 265 (5593), 421-4 ISSN:0028-0836.
        The culture lifetime of epidermal cells of newborn humans is increased from 50 to 150 generations by adding to the medium epidermal growth factor, a polypeptide mitogen. EGF seems to delay senescence of the cells by maintaining them in a state further removed from terminal differentiation. This effect is revealed by a greater ability of the cells to survive subculture and initiate new colonies, but not necessarily by an increased growth rate.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®

      14. 14
        De Larco, J. E.; Todaro, G. J. Growth factors from murine sarcoma virus-transformed cells. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1978, 75, 4001, Â DOI: 10.1073/pnas.75.8.4001
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        14
        Growth factors from murine sarcoma virus-transformed cells
        De Larco, Joseph E.; Todaro, George J.
        Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (1978), 75 (8), 4001-5CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424.
        Murine sarcoma virus-transformed mouse fibroblasts produced polypeptide growth factors and released them into serum-free medium. These factors stimulated cells to divide in monolayer cultures and also to form colonies that grew progressively in soft agar. Three major peaks of activity were seen, with apparent mol. wts. of 25,000, 12,000, and 7000. The sarcoma growth factors were heat-stable, trypsin-sensitive, and active in ng quantities when tested for growth stimulation of untransformed rat and mouse fibroblasts. All three mol. species were capable of competing for membrane epidermal growth factor (EGF) receptors when tested with 125I-labeled EGF. They differed from mouse EGF in their mol. wts., in their inability to react with anti-EGF antibodies, and in their ability to convert cells to anchorage independent (agar) growth. For the above reasons, it was concluded that the sarcoma growth factors are a new class of polypeptide tropic factors that confer on fibroblasts in vitro properties assocd. with the transformed phenotype.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaE1cXls1Whs7s%253D&md5=064e6cda6baeb79ec646382317e7e7bb
      15. 15
        Higashiyama, S.; Abraham, J. A.; Miller, J.; Fiddes, J. C.; Klagsbrun, M. A heparin-binding growth factor secreted by macrophage-like cells that is related to EGF. Science 1991, 251, 936â 939, Â DOI: 10.1126/science.1840698
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        15
        A heparin-binding growth factor secreted by macrophage-like cells that is related to EGF
        Higashiyama, Shigeki; Abraham, Judith A.; Miller, Judy; Fiddes, John C.; Klagsbrun, Michael
        Science (Washington, DC, United States) (1991), 251 (4996), 936-9CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075.
        Macrophage-like U-937 cells secrete a 22-kilodalton heparin-binding growth factor that is mitogenic for BALB-3T3 fibroblasts and smooth muscle cells, but not endothelial cells. The amino acid sequence predicted from cDNA clones indicates that the mitogen is a new member of the epidermal growth factor (EGF) family. This heparin-binding EGF-like growth factor (HB-EGF) binds to EGF receptors on A-431 epidermoid carcinoma cells and smooth muscle cells, but is a far more potent mitogen for smooth muscle cells than is EGF. HB-EGF is also expressed in cultured human macrophages and may be involved in macrophage-mediated cellular proliferation.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK3MXlt1ygtrk%253D&md5=9f180c23bdda4291ca1ce22f69c7754d
      16. 16
        Shing, Y.; Christofori, G.; Hanahan, D.; Ono, Y.; Sasada, R.; Igarashi, K.; Folkman, J. Betacellulin: a mitogen from pancreatic beta cell tumors. Science 1993, 259, 1604â 1607, Â DOI: 10.1126/science.8456283
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        16
        Betacellulin: a mitogen from pancreatic Î² cell tumors
        Shing, Y.; Christofori, G.; Hanahan, D.; Ono, Y.; Sasada, R.; Igarashi, K.; Folkman, J.
        Science (Washington, DC, United States) (1993), 259 (5101), 1604-7CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075.
        Betacellulin, a member of the epidermal growth factor family, has been identified in the conditioned medium of cell lines derived from mouse pancreatic Î² cell tumors. Betacellulin is a 32-kilodalton glycoprotein that appears to be processed from a larger transmembrane precursor by proteolytic cleavage. The carboxyl-terminal domain of betacellulin has 50 percent sequence similarity with that of rat transforming growth factor Î±. Betacellulin is a potent mitogen for retinal pigment epithelial cells and vascular smooth muscle cells.

        Shoyab, M.; Plowman, G. D.; McDonald, V. L.; Bradley, J. G.; Todaro, G. J. Structure and function of human amphiregulin: a member of the epidermal growth factor family. Science 1989, 243, 1074â 1076, Â DOI: 10.1126/science.2466334
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        17
        Structure and function of human amphiregulin: a member of the epidermal growth factor family
        Shoyab, Mohammed; Plowman, Gregory D.; McDonald, Vicki L.; Bradley, J. Garrett; Todaro, George J.
        Science (Washington, DC, United States) (1989), 243 (4894, Pt. 1), 1074-6CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075.
        The complete amino acid sequence of amphiregulin, a bifunctional cell growth modulator, was detd. The truncated form contains 78 amino acids, whereas a larger form of amphiregulin contains 6 addnl. amino acids at the amino-terminal end. The amino-terminal half of amphiregulin is extremely hydrophilic and contains unusually high nos. of lysine, arginine, and asparagine residues. The carboxyl-terminal half of amphiregulin (residues 46 to 84) exhibits striking homol. to the EGF family of proteins. Amphiregulin binds to the EGF receptor but not as well as EGF does. Amphiregulin fully supplants the requirement for EGF or transforming growth factor-Î± in murine keratinocyte growth, but it is a much weaker growth stimulator in other cell systems.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL1MXitVGqt74%253D&md5=73c4e09eb6373dcddc94cf9f56935ed8
      18. 18
        Shoyab, M.; McDonald, V. L.; Bradley, J. G.; Todaro, G. J. Amphiregulin: a bifunctional growth-modulating glycoprotein produced by the phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate-treated human breast adenocarcinoma cell line MCF-7. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S.         18
        Amphiregulin: a bifunctional growth-modulating glycoprotein produced by the phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate-treated human breast adenocarcinoma cell line MCF-7
        Shoyab, Mohammed; McDonald, Vicki L.; Bradley, J. Garrett; Todaro, George J.
        Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (1988), 85 (17), 6528-32CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424.
        A glycoprotein, termed amphiregulin (AR), inhibits the growth of several human carcinoma cells in culture and stimulates proliferation of human fibroblasts and certain other tumor cells. It has been purified to apparent homogeneity from serum-free conditioned medium of MCF-7 human breast carcinoma cells that had been treated with phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate. AR is a single-chain extremely hydrophilic glycoprotein contg. cysteines in disulfide linkage(s) that are essential for biol. activity; it is stable between pH 2 and pH 12 and after heating for 30 min at 56Â° but unstable at 100Â°. The apparent mol. wts. of AR and N-glycanase-treated AR are 14,000 and 15,000, resp., as assessed by gel chromatog., and â22,500 and â14,000, resp., as detd. by PAGE. Treatment of AR with N-glycanase, O-glycanase, or neuraminidase does not affect its activity. The pI of AR is â7.8. The amino-terminal amino acid sequence of AR has been detd., and no significant sequence homol. between AR and other proteins was found. The mol. thus appears to be a distinct growth regulatory protein.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL1cXlvVyisbc%253D&md5=f6013e8f99099f53ebbc5250710dde45
      19. 19
        Toyoda, H.; Komurasaki, T.; Uchida, D.; Takayama, Y.; Isobe, T.; Okuyama, T.; Hanada, K. Epiregulin a novel epidermal growth factor with mitogenic activity for rat primary hepatocytes. J. Biol. Chem. 1995, 270, 7495â 7500, Â DOI: 10.1074/jbc.270.13.7495
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        19
        A novel epidermal growth factor with mitogenic activity for rat primary hepatocytes
        Toyoda, Hitoshi; Komurasaki, Toshi; Uchida, Daisuke; Takayama, Yasuko; Isobe, Toshiaki; Okuyama, Tuneo; Hanada, Kazunori
        Journal of Biological Chemistry (1995), 270 (13), 7495-500CODEN: JBCHA3; ISSN:0021-9258. (American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology)
        Epiregulin, a novel epidermal growth factor (EGF)-related growth regulating peptide, was purified from conditioned medium of the mouse fibroblast-derived tumor cell line NIH3T3/clone T7. It was a 46-amino-acid single chain polypeptide, and its amino acid sequence exhibited 24-50% amino acid sequence identity with sequences of other EGF-related growth factors. Epiregulin exhibited bifunctional regulatory properties: it inhibited the growth of several epithelial tumor cells and stimulated the growth of fibroblasts and various other types of cells. Epiregulin bound to the EGF receptors of epidermoid carcinoma A431 cells much more weakly than did EGF, but was nevertheless much more potent than EGF as a mitogen for rat primary hepatocytes and Balb/c 3T3 A31 fibroblasts. These findings suggest that epiregulin plays important roles in regulating the growth of epithelial cells and fibroblasts by binding to receptors for EGF-related ligands.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2MXkvVOjsLc%253D&md5=f3af4fc255d95fd6cd9a2faf9140da66
      20. 20
        Strachan, L.; Murison, J. G.; Prestidge, R. L.; Sleeman, M. A.; Watson, J. D.; Kumble, K. D. Cloning and biological activity of epigen, a novel member of the epidermal growth factor superfamily. J. Biol. Chem. 2001, 276, 18265â 18271, Â DOI: 10.1074/jbc.M006935200
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        20
        Cloning and biological activity of Epigen, a novel member of the epidermal growth factor superfamily
        Strachan, Lorna; Murison, J. Greg; Prestidge, Ross L.; Sleeman, Matthew A.; Watson, James D.; Kumble, Krishnanand D.
        Journal of Biological Chemistry (2001), 276 (21), 18265-18271CODEN: JBCHA3; ISSN:0021-9258. (American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology)
        High throughput sequencing of a mouse keratinocyte library was used to identify an expressed sequence tag with homol. to the epidermal growth factor (EGF) family of growth factors. The authors have named the protein encoded by this expressed sequence tag Epigen, for epithelial mitogen. Epigen encodes a protein of 152 amino acids that contains features characteristic of the EGF superfamily. Two hydrophobic regions, corresponding to a putative signal sequence and transmembrane domain, flank a core of amino acids encompassing six cysteine residues and two putative N-linked glycosylation sites. Epigen shows 24-37% identity to members of the EGF superfamily including EGF, transforming growth factor Î±, and Epiregulin. Northern blotting of several adult mouse tissues indicated that Epigen was present in testis, heart, and liver. Recombinant Epigen was synthesized in Escherichia coli and refolded, and its biol. activity was compared with that of EGF and transforming growth factor Î± in several assays. In epithelial cells, Epigen stimulated the phosphorylation of c-erbB-1 and mitogen-activated protein kinases and also activated a reporter gene contg. enhancer sequences present in the c-fos promoter. Epigen also stimulated the proliferation of HaCaT cells, and this proliferation was blocked by an antibody to the extracellular domain of the receptor tyrosine kinase c-erbB-1. Thus, Epigen is the newest member of the EGF superfamily and, with its ability to promote the growth of epithelial cells, may constitute a novel mol. target for wound-healing therapy.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXktFWmtr4%253D&md5=303932b3fc2f119947e0a15c1ce9ca5f

        Chang, W.; Upton, C.; Hu, S.-L.; Purchio, A.; McFadden, G.         21
        The genome of Shope fibroma virus, a tumorigenic poxvirus, contains a growth factor gene with sequence similarity to those encoding epidermal growth factor and transforming growth factor alpha
        Chang, Wen; Upton, Chris; Hu, Shiu Lok; Purchio, A. F.; McFadden, Grant
        Molecular and Cellular Biology (1987), 7 (1), 535-40CODEN: MCEBD4; ISSN:0270-7306.
        Degenerate oligonucleotide probes corresponding to a highly conserved region common to epidermal growth factor, transforming growth factor alpha, and vaccinia growth factor were used to identify a novel growth factor gene in the Shope fibroma virus genome. Sequence anal. indicates that the Shope fibroma growth factor is a distinct new member of this family of growth factors.

        22
        The gene lin-3 encodes an inductive signal for vulval development in C. elegans
        Hill, Russell J.; Sternberg, Paul W.
        Nature (London, United Kingdom) (1992), 358 (6386), 470-6CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836.
        The lin-3 gene is necessary for induction of the Caenorhabditis elegans vulva by the anchor cell. It encodes a mol. similar to epidermal growth factor and to transforming growth factor-Î± and acts through the epidermal growth factor receptor homolog let-23. Expression of lin-3 in the anchor cell stimulates vulval induction; lin-3 may encode the vulval inducing signal.

        Rutledge, B.; Zhang, K.; Bier, E.; Jan, Y.; Perrimon, N. The Drosophila spitz gene encodes a putative EGF-like growth factor involved in dorsal-ventral axis formation and neurogenesis. Genes Dev. 1992, 6, 1503â 1517, Â DOI: 10.1101/gad.6.8.1503
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        23
        The Drosophila spitz gene encodes a putative EGF-like growth factor involved in dorsal-ventral axis formation and neurogenesis
        Rutledge, Barbara J.; Zhang, Kang; Bier, Ethan; Jan, Yuh Nung; Perrimon, Norbert
        Genes & Development (1992), 6 (8), 1503-17CODEN: GEDEEP; ISSN:0890-9369.
        The mol. characterization of the Drosophila melanogaster gene spitz (spi), which encodes a putative 26-kDa, EGF-like transmembrane protein that is structurally similar to TGF-Î±, is described. Temporal and spatial expression patterns of spi transcripts indicate that spi is expressed throughout the embryo. Examn. of mutant embryos reveals that spi is involved in a no. of unrelated developmental choices, for example, dorsal-ventral axis formation, glial migration, sensory organ detn., and muscle development. Thus, spi may act as a ligand for cell-specific receptors, possibly rhomboid and/or the Drosophila EGF receptor homolog.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK3sXktVajtbY%253D&md5=8f720359d1d26c96b7e9298b736e5a6f
      24. 24
        Ye, Y.-K.; Lin, Y.-Z.; Tam, J. P. Shope fibroma virus growth factor exhibits epidermal growth factor activities in newborn mice. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1988, 154, 497â 501, Â DOI: 10.1016/0006-291X(88)90167-2
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        24
        Shope fibroma virus growth factor exhibits epidermal growth factor activities in newborn mice
        Ye, Yuang Kang; Lin, Yao Zhong; Tam, James P.
        Biochemical and Biophysical Research Communications (1988), 154 (2), 497-501CODEN: BBRCA9; ISSN:0006-291X.
        A synthetic 55-residue peptide consisting of the C portion of the predicted genomic DNA sequence of Shope fibroma virus growth factor (SFGF residue 26-80) exhibited EGF-transforming growth factor activities in newborn mice. The synthetic SFGF accelerated precocious incisor eruption and eyelid opening in newborn mice and also retarded the overall growth rates of hair, body wt., and body length when administered in dosages of 4-6 Î¼g/g body wt. The results of whole animal studies indicate that SFGF belongs to the EGF-TGFÎ± family and exerts similar biol. effects in newborn animals.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL1cXlt1eis7g%253D&md5=b52416f0e6edf2cea0d9fcb455b79178
      25. 25
        Bui, T. Q.; Bui, Q. V. P.; NÃ©meth, D.; Hegyi, P.; SzakÃ¡cs, Z.; Rumbus, Z.; TÃ³th, B.; Emri, G.; PÃ¡rniczky, A.; SarlÃ³s, P. Epidermal growth factor is effective in the treatment of diabetic foot ulcers: meta-analysis and systematic review. Int. J. Environ. Res. 2019, 16, 2584, Â DOI: 10.3390/ijerph16142584
        [Crossref], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        25
        Epidermal growth factor is e effective in the treatment of diabetic foot ulcers: meta-analysis and systematic review
        Bui, Thien Quoc; Van Phu Bui, Quoc; Nemeth, David; Hegyi, Peter; Szakacs, Zsolt; Rumbus, Zoltan; Toth, Barbara; Emri, Gabriella; Parniczky, Andrea; Sarlos, Patricia; Varga, Orsolya
        International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health (2019), 16 (14), 2584CODEN: IJERGQ; ISSN:1660-4601. (MDPI AG)
        A review. Diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs) are one the common complications of diabetes mellitus. Many trials were performed to evaluate the effect of recombinant human epidermal growth factor (rhEGF) in healing DFUs. This meta-anal. was performed to synthesize the evidence of rhEGF treatment in DFUs in comparison to placebo. Databases included for the search were PubMed, EMBASE, the Cochrane Library, Web of Science, EBSCOhost, ScienceDirect, and Scopus (up to Jan. 2019). The outcome of interest was the complete healing rate of DFUs. We performed random effects meta-anal. stratified by the types of administration route (intralesional injection and topical apply) by calcg. the odds ratios (OR) and 95% confidence interval (95% CI). A total of six studies involving 530 patients were eligible for anal. The combined OR (intralesional injection and topical apply) was 4.005 (95% CI: (2.248; 7.135), p < 0.001). The ORs for intralesional injection and topical application were 3.599 (95% CI: (1.213; 10.677), p = 0.021) and 4.176 (95% CI: (2.112; 8.256), p < 0.001), resp. Statistical heterogeneity might not be important in overall treatment (I2 = 15.17, p = 0.317) and both of the subgroups (I2: 24.56, p = 0.25 and I2: 33.26, p = 0.213, resp.). Our results support the use of rhEGF in the treatment of DFUs.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXisVCmurvF&md5=4eb9cf8ceee00cb9471f623ac6c2fdb8
      26. 26
        Brown, G. L.; Nanney, L. B.; Griffen, J.; Cramer, A. B.; Yancey, J. M.; Curtsinger, L. J., III; Holtzin, L.; Schultz, G. S.; Jurkiewicz, M. J.; Lynch, J. B. Enhancement of wound healing by topical treatment with epidermal growth factor. N. Engl. J. Med. 1989, 321, 76â 79, Â DOI: 10.1056/NEJM198907133210203
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        26
        Enhancement of wound healing by topical treatment with epidermal growth factor
        Brown G L; Nanney L B; Griffen J; Cramer A B; Yancey J M; Curtsinger L J 3rd; Holtzin L; Schultz G S; Jurkiewicz M J; Lynch J B
        The New England journal of medicine (1989), 321 (2), 76-9 ISSN:0028-4793.
        Experimental studies in animals have demonstrated that the topical application of epidermal growth factor accelerates the rate of epidermal regeneration of partial-thickness wounds and second-degree burns. We conducted a prospective, randomized, double-blind clinical trial using skin-graft-donor sites to determine whether epidermal growth factor would accelerate the rate of epidermal regeneration in humans. Paired donor sites were created in 12 patients who required skin grafting for either burns or reconstructive surgery. One donor site from each patient was treated topically with silver sulfadiazine cream, and one was treated with silver sulfadiazine cream containing epidermal growth factor (10 micrograms per milliliter). The donor sites were photographed daily, and healing was measured with the use of planimetric analysis. The donor sites treated with silver sulfadiazine containing epidermal growth factor had an accelerated rate of epidermal regeneration in all 12 patients as compared with that in the paired donor sites treated with silver sulfadiazine alone. Treatment with epidermal growth factor significantly decreased the average length of time to 25 percent and 50 percent healing by approximately one day and that to 75 percent and 100 percent healing by approximately 1.5 days (P less than 0.02). Histologic evaluation of punch-biopsy specimens taken from the centers of donor sites three days after the onset of healing supported these results. We conclude that epidermal growth factor accelerates the rate of healing of partial-thickness skin wounds. Further studies are required to determine the clinical importance of this finding.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADyaL1M3otFKmtQ%253D%253D&md5=48eb24f3a6692b72b09003115f1a3a66
      27. 27
        Gurtner, G. C.; Werner, S.; Barrandon, Y.; Longaker, M. T. Wound repair and regeneration. Nature 2008, 453, 314, Â DOI: 10.1038/nature07039
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        27
        Wound repair and regeneration
        Gurtner, Geoffrey C.; Werner, Sabine; Barrandon, Yann; Longaker, Michael T.
        Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2008), 453 (7193), 314-321CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
        A review. The repair of wounds is one of the most complex biol. processes that occur during human life. After an injury, multiple biol. pathways immediately become activated and are synchronized to respond. In human adults, the wound repair process commonly leads to a non-functioning mass of fibrotic tissue known as a scar. By contrast, early in gestation, injured fetal tissues can be completely recreated, without fibrosis, in a process resembling regeneration. Some organisms, however, retain the ability to regenerate tissue throughout adult life. Knowledge gained from studying such organisms might help to unlock latent regenerative pathways in humans, which would change medical practice as much as the introduction of antibiotics did in the twentieth century.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXlvV2qtbk%253D&md5=38a1d3f2b74912936ea5584bea30cbd0

        [Crossref], [CAS],Â Google Scholar

        Science, medicine and the future: healing chronic wounds
        Harding K G; Morris H L; Patel G K
        BMJ (Clinical research ed.) (2002), 324 (7330), 160-3 ISSN:0959-8138.
        Greater interest in wound healing is needed to ensure higher standards of basic care. Precise identification of the systemic, local, and molecular factors underlying the wound healing problem in individual patients should allow better tailored treatment. Allogeneic skin grafting and bioengineered skin equivalents are being used successfully in patients with venous leg ulcers and diabetic patients with foot ulcers.

      29. 29
        Olsson, M.; JÃ¤rbrink, K.; Divakar, U.; Bajpai, R.; Upton, Z.; Schmidtchen, A.; Car, J. The humanistic and economic burden of chronic wounds: A systematic review. Wound Repair Regen. 2019, 27, 114â 125, Â DOI: 10.1111/wrr.12683
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        29
        The humanistic and economic burden of chronic wounds: A systematic review
        Olsson Maja; Jarbrink Krister; Divakar Ushashree; Bajpai Ram; Car Josip; Upton Zee; Upton Zee; Schmidtchen Artur; Schmidtchen Artur; Car Josip
        Wound repair and regeneration : official publication of the Wound Healing Society [and] the European Tissue Repair Society (2019), 27 (1), 114-125 ISSN:.
        Chronic wounds are a health problem that have devastating consequences for patients and contribute major costs to healthcare systems and societies. To understand the magnitude of this health issue, a systematic review was undertaken. Searches were conducted in MEDLINE, EMBASE, EBM Reviews and Cochrane library, CINAHL, EBSCO, PsycINFO, and Global Health databases for articles published between 2000 and 2015. Included publications had to target adults (â¥18 years of age), state wound chronicity (â¥3 weeks) and/or label the wounds as chronic, complex, hard-to-heal, or having led to an amputation. The review excluded studies that did not present data on generic health-related quality of life and/or cost data, case studies, randomized controlled trials, economic modeling studies, abstracts, and editorials. Extracted data were summarized into a narrative synthesis, and for a few articles using the same health-related quality of life instrument, average estimates with 95% confidence intervals were calculated. Thirty articles met the inclusion criteria. Findings revealed that health-related quality of life was lowest for physical pathologies, and based on average estimates were scores most inferior in the domain physical role for both patients with chronic wounds and for those with wound-related amputations. The cost burden was mainly attributed to amputations for patients also comorbid with diabetes, where the cost for hospitalization ranged from US$12,851 to US$16,267 (median) for this patient group. Patients with chronic wounds have poor health-related quality of life in general and wound-related costs are substantial. Development and implementation of wound management strategies that focus on increasing health-related quality of life and effectively reduce costs for this patient group are urgently needed.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BB3cvjsVKmtg%253D%253D&md5=17df35505adf12f73de1efa1cc853750

      32. 32
        Boulton, A. J.; Vileikyte, L.; Ragnarson-Tennvall, G.; Apelqvist, J. The global burden of diabetic foot disease. Lancet 2005, 366, 1719â 1724, Â DOI: 10.1016/S0140-6736(05)67698-2
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        32
        The global burden of diabetic foot disease
        Boulton Andrew J M; Vileikyte Loretta; Ragnarson-Tennvall Gunnel; Apelqvist Jan
        Lancet (London, England) (2005), 366 (9498), 1719-24 ISSN:.
        Diabetic foot problems are common throughout the world, resulting in major economic consequences for the patients, their families, and society. Foot ulcers are more likely to be of neuropathic origin, and therefore eminently preventable, in developing countries, which will experience the greatest rise in the prevalence of type 2 diabetes in the next 20 years. People at greatest risk of ulceration can easily be identified by careful clinical examination of the feet: education and frequent follow-up is indicated for these patients. When assessing the economic effects of diabetic foot disease, it is important to remember that rates of recurrence of foot ulcers are very high, being greater than 50% after 3 years. Costing should therefore include not only the immediate ulcer episode, but also social services, home care, and subsequent ulcer episodes. A broader view of total resource use should include some estimate of quality of life and the final outcome. An integrated care approach with regular screening and education of patients at risk requires low expenditure and has the potential to reduce the cost of health care.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BD2MnhtlKgtQ%253D%253D&md5=0da1cc5067e1ab9b23a3606f7f655601

        Financial burden of diabetic foot ulcers to world: a progressive topic to discuss always
        Raghav Alok; Khan Zeeshan Ahmad; Labala Rajendra Kumar; Ahmad Jamal; Noor Saba; Mishra Brijesh Kumar

        Diabetic foot complications are the most common occurring problems throughout the globe, resulting in devastating economic crises for the patients, families and society. Diabetic patients that are of greatest risk of ulcers may easily be diagnosed with foot examination. Economic burden may be carefully examined. The budget costing must include both the clinical and social impact of the patients.

      35. 35
        Goldman, R. Growth factors and chronic wound healing: past, present, and future. Adv. Skin Wound Care 2004, 17, 24â 35, Â DOI: 10.1097/00129334-200401000-00012
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        35
        Growth factors and chronic wound healing: past, present, and future
        Goldman Robert
        Advances in skin & wound care (2004), 17 (1), 24-35 ISSN:1527-7941.
        Growth substances (cytokines and growth factors) are soluble signaling proteins affecting the process of normal wound healing. Cytokines govern the inflammatory phase that clears cellular and extracellular matrix debris. Wound repair is controlled by growth factors (platelet-derived growth factor [PDGF], keratinocyte growth factor, and transforming growth factor beta). Endogenous growth factors communicate across the dermal-epidermal interface. PDGF is important for most phases of wound healing. Becaplermin (PDGF-BB), the only growth factor approved by the Food and Drug Administration, requires daily application for neuropathic wound healing. Gene therapy is under development for more efficient growth factor delivery; a single application will induce constitutive growth factor expression for weeks. Based on dramatic preclinical animal studies, a phase 1 clinical trial planned on a PDGF genetic construct appears promising.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BD2c%252FltVWjtA%253D%253D&md5=519fb0b96baa974a2fe5ad2dd9aaf1f3

        Ãelebi, N.; TÃ¼rkyilmaz, A.; GÃ¶nÃ¼l, B.; Ãzogul, C. Effects of epidermal growth factor microemulsion formulation on the healing of stress-induced gastric ulcers in rats. J. Control. Release 2002, 83, 197â 210, Â DOI: 10.1016/S0168-3659(02)00198-0
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        37
        Effects of epidermal growth factor microemulsion formulation on the healing of stress-induced gastric ulcers in rats
        Celebi, Nevin; Turkyilmaz, Ali; Gonul, Bilge; Ozogul, Candan
        Journal of Controlled Release (2002), 83 (2), 197-210CODEN: JCREEC; ISSN:0168-3659. (Elsevier Science Ltd.)
        The effects of intragastric (i.g.) administration of microemulsion formulation of epidermal growth factor (EGF) on the healing of acute gastric ulcers induced by cold-restraint stress in rats was studied and compared with i.p. administration of solns. In the microemulsion formulation (W/O), Labrafil M 1944 CS was the oil phase. Arlacel 186 and Brij 35 were used as the surfactants. Abs. alc. and distd. water were used as the co-surfactant and the aq. phase, resp. Acute gastric lesions were induced by cold-restraint stress for 4 h in the refrigerator (4.0Â±0.5 Â°C). EGF was administered at a dose of 6 Î¼g/kg per day i.p. and i.p. for 7 days. Basal gastric acid secretion (Î¼equiv. H+/30 min), ulcer score (mm2) and tissue mucus levels (Î¼g/g tissue) were measured. Basal gastric secretion was significantly reduced after the administration of EGF microemulsion (ME+EGF) (P<0.05). There was no significant decrease in basal gastric acid secretion following i.p (IPEGF) and i.g (IG-EGF) of EGF administrations of solns. compared to their control groups (P>0.05). The results indicate that the highest redn. in the basal acid secretion was seen after the administration of a microemulsion of EGF formulation. The mean ulcer score was reduced by i.g treatment with the microemulsion dosage form of EGF in 7 days from 15.9Â±1.4 to 1.16Â±0.45 mm2 and was almost completely healed in four of the animals. The results demonstrate that the ulcer score was significantly reduced in i.p. (IPEGF) soln. (P<0.005), i.g (IG-EGF) soln. (P<0.01) and i.g. microemulsion (ME+EGF) (P<0.01) treated groups compared to untreated group. In IG-EGF, ME+EGF treated groups, mucus levels increased significantly compared to their control groups (P<0.05 and P<0.01). In contrast, there was no significant change in the mucus levels following i.p. EGF administration (P>0.05).

        Tanaka, A.; Nagate, T.; Matsuda, H. Acceleration of wound healing by gelatin film dressings with epidermal growth factor. J. Vet. Med. Sci. 2005, 67, 909â 913, Â DOI: 10.1292/jvms.67.909
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        38
        Acceleration of wound healing by gelatin film dressings with epidermal growth factor
        Tanaka, Akane; Nagate, Toshiaki; Matsuda, Hiroshi
        Journal of Veterinary Medical Science (2005), 67 (9), 909-913CODEN: JVMSEQ; ISSN:0916-7250. (Japanese Society of Veterinary Science)
        We examd. in vivo efficiency of a gelatin film sheet with epidermal growth factor (EGF) for a novel therapeutic device for cutaneous wound repair. NIH3T3 fibroblasts and PAM212 keratinocytes proliferated when the cells were incubated with the homogenate of EGF contg. gelatin sheets, indicating that the gelatin sheet retained biol. activity of EGF in the process of sheet formation. To evaluate therapeutic effects, the EGF contg. gelatin sheets or control sheets were applied onto partial-thickness skin wounds made on dorsa of hairless dogs. Wound closure in wounds treated with EGF contg. gelatin sheets was accelerated when compared to that of wounds treated with control sheets, exhibiting earlier reepithelialization of the epidermis and highly regulated repair of extracellular matrix in the dermis. Therefore, we concluded that the gelatin film is a useful material to keep EGF stable and the EGF contg. sheet has the ability to become an efficient therapeutic agent for superficial or deep partial-thickness wounds in the skin.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®

        Kiyohara, Y.; Komada, F.; Iwakawa, S.; Hirai, M.; Fuwa, T.; Okumura, K. Improvement in wound healing by epidermal growth factor (EGF) ointment. II. Effect of protease inhibitor, nafamostat, on stabilization and efficacy of EGF in burn. J. Pharmacobio-Dyn. 1991, 14, 47â 52, Â DOI: 10.1248/bpb1978.14.47
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        39
        Improvement in wound healing by epidermal growth factor (EGF) ointment. II. Effect of protease inhibitor, nafamostat, on stabilization and efficacy of EGF in burn
        Kiyohara, Yoshifumi; Komada, Fusao; Iwakawa, Seigo; Hirai, Midori; Fuwa, Tohru; Okumura, Katsuhiko
        Journal of Pharmacobio-Dynamics (1991), 14 (1), 47-52CODEN: JOPHDQ; ISSN:0386-846X.
        The healing effect of human(h) EGF on 2nd degree burn was studied in rats. No improvement in wound healing was found on topical application of EGF alone to burn sites, but an ointment contg. EGF and nafamostat mesilate (NM), a protease inhibitor, accelerated the healing rate of burns. The dry wt. of the granulation tissue on the wound site in the group treated with EGF plus NM ointment did not change, although that in other groups decreased. After treatment with EGF ointment contg. NM, the content of uronic acid, an index of acid mucopolysaccharide, 3 days after burn rapidly increased and recovered to nearly normal levels at 7 days after burn. However, the uronic acid content in the other groups (control, EGF alone, and NM alone) showed a higher value at 7 days than at 3. When compared with the control values increases in hydroxyproline, as an index of collagen, in the wound site were obsd. 7 days after treatment with EGF ointment contg. NM. The degrdn. of [125I]EGF in burned tissue homogenate decreased in a concn.-dependent manner in the presence of NM. Body wt. did not change after treatment with EGF plus NM ointment, although the body wts. of other treatment groups decreased after burn, suggesting that EGF ointment contg. the protease inhibitor, NM, alleviated the effects of burn shock. Evidently, the stabilization of EGF at the wound site is an important factor for the expression of its healing action.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK3MXhsFOlt78%253D&md5=8b646dd5ee85f3a53cd3569151ac4fe2
      40. 40
        Okumura, K.; Kiyohara, Y.; Komada, F.; Iwakawa, S.; Hirai, M.; Fuwa, T. Improvement in wound healing by epidermal growth factor (EGF) ointment. I. Effect of nafamostat, gabexate, or gelatin on stabilization and efficacy of EGF. Pharm. Res. 1990, 07, 1289â 1293, Â DOI: 10.1023/A:1015946123697
        [Crossref], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        40
        Improvement in wound healing by epidermal growth factor (EGF) ointment. I. Effect of nafamostat, gabexate, or gelatin on stabilization and efficacy of EGF
        Okumura, Katsuhiko; Kiyohara, Yoshifumi; Komada, Fusao; Iwakawa, Seigo; Hirai, Midori; Fuwa, Tohru
        Pharmaceutical Research (1990), 7 (12), 1289-93CODEN: PHREEB; ISSN:0724-8741.
        The healing effect of human (h) EGF on open wounds was studied in rats. No improvement in wound healing was found by topical application of EGF alone to open wound sites. However, an ointment contg. EGF and a protease inhibitor, nafamostat mesilate or gabexate mesilate, or gelatin accelerated the healing rate of open wounds. Increases in the dry wt. of the wound site granulation tissue, uronic acid (as an index of acid mucopolysaccharide), and hydroxyproline (as an index of collagen) were obsd. by treatment with EGF ointment contg. nafamostat compared with the controls. The effects of the protease inhibitor on wound healing were dose dependent. Nafamostat was more efficient than gebexate or gelatin on wound healing. The degrdn. of 125I-IGF in wound tissue homogenate was decreased in the presence of a protease inhibitor, such as nafamostat or gabexate, or gelatin. These findings indicate that the stabilization of EGF at the wound site is an important factor in permitting the expression of its healing effects and suggest that the ointment contg. EGF and a stabilizing agent would be a suitable dosage form for acceleration of wound repair.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK3MXjs1KhsQ%253D%253D&md5=a5286a8622d8306d110927f32c046ff0

        Kam, A.; Loo, S.; Dutta, B.; Sze, S. K.; Tam, J. P. Plant-derived mitochondria-targeting cysteine-rich peptide modulates cellular bioenergetics. J. Biol. Chem. 2019, 294, 4000, Â DOI: 10.1074/jbc.RA118.006693
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        41
        Plant-derived mitochondria-targeting cysteine-rich peptide modulates cellular bioenergetics
        Kam, Antony; Loo, Shining; Dutta, Bamaprasad; Sze, Siu Kwan; Tam, James P.
        Journal of Biological Chemistry (2019), 294 (11), 4000-4011CODEN: JBCHA3; ISSN:0021-9258. (American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology)
        Mitochondria are attractive therapeutic targets for developing agents to delay age-related frailty and diseases. However, few promising leads have been identified from natural products. Previously, we identified roseltide rT1, a hyperstable 27-residue cysteine-rich peptide from Hibiscus sabdariffa, as a knottintype neutrophil elastase inhibitor. Here, we show that roseltide rT1 is also a cell-penetrating, mitochondria-targeting peptide that increases ATP prodn. Results from flow cytometry, live-cell imaging, pulldown assays, and genetically-modified cell lines supported that roseltide rT1 enters cells via glycosaminoglycan-dependent endocytosis, and enters the mitochondria through TOM20, a mitochondrial protein import receptor. We further showed that roseltide rT1 increases cellular ATP prodn. via mitochondrial membrane hyperpolarization. Using biotinylated roseltide rT1 for target identification and proteomic anal., we showed that human mitochondrial membrane ATP synthase subunit O is an intramitochondrial target. Collectively, these data support our discovery that roseltide rT1 is a 1st-in-class mitochondria-targeting, cysteine-rich peptide with potentials to be developed into tools to further our understanding of mitochondria-related diseases.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXpvFSmtrc%253D&md5=0f7d091d7e2920c1dea58fde6c1bccf9
      42. 42
        Loo, S.; Kam, A.; Xiao, T.; Tam, J. P. Bleogens: cactus-derived anti-candida cysteine-rich peptides with three different precursor arrangements. Front. Plant Sci. 2017, 8, 2162, Â DOI: 10.3389/fpls.2017.02162
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        42
        Bleogens: Cactus-Derived Anti-Candida Cysteine-Rich Peptides with Three Different Precursor Arrangements
        Loo Shining; Kam Antony; Xiao Tianshu; Tam James P
        Frontiers in plant science (2017), 8 (), 2162 ISSN:1664-462X.
        Cysteine-rich peptides (CRPs) play important host-defense roles in plants. However, information concerning CRPs in the Cactaceae (cactus) family is limited, with only a single cactus-derived CRP described to date. Here, we report the identification of 15 novel CRPs with three different precursor architectures, bleogens pB1-15 from Pereskia bleo of the Cactaceae family. By combining proteomic and transcriptomic methods, we showed that the prototype, bleogen pB1, contained 36 amino acid residues, a six-cysteine motif typical of the six-cysteine-hevein-like peptide (6C-HLP) family, and a type I two-domain precursor consisting of an endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and a mature domain. In contrast, the precursors of the other 14 bleogens contained a type II three-domain architecture with a propeptide domain inserted between the ER and the mature bleogen domain. Four of these 14 bleogens display a third type of architecture with a tandemly repeating bleogen domain. A search of the Onekp database revealed that <1% plant species possess three different precursor architectures for the biosynthesis of 6C-HLPs, including Lophophora williamsii, Pereskia aculeate, Portulaca cryptopetala, Portulaca oleracea, Portulaca suffruticosa, and Talinum sp. NMR analysis confirmed that bleogen pB1 has cystine-knot disulfide connectivity as well as a two-beta-sheet and a four-loop structural fold that is similar to other 6C-HLPs. Sequence analysis, structural studies, and in silico modeling revealed that bleogen pB1 has a cation-polar-cation motif, a signature heparin-binding motif that was confirmed by heparin affinity chromatography. Cell-based assays showed that bleogen pB1 is non-toxic to mammalian cells but functions as an anti-Candida peptide. Taken together, our findings provide insight into the occurrence, functions and precursor architectures of CRPs in the cactus family.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC1MzosF2lug%253D%253D&md5=b82ca2c38cac77586b54117e58079f98
      43. 43
        Tam, J. P.; Nguyen, G. K.; Loo, S.; Wang, S.; Yang, D.; Kam, A. Ginsentides: cysteine and glycine-rich peptides from the ginseng family with unusual disulfide connectivity. Sci. Rep. 2018, 8, 16201 Â DOI: 10.1038/s41598-018-33894-x
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        43
        Ginsentides: Cysteine and Glycine-rich Peptides from the Ginseng Family with Unusual Disulfide Connectivity
        Tam James P; Nguyen Giang K T; Loo Shining; Wang Shujing; Kam Antony; Nguyen Giang K T; Wang Shujing; Yang Daiwen
        Scientific reports (2018), 8 (1), 16201 ISSN:.
        Ginseng, a popular and valuable traditional medicine, has been used for centuries to maintain health and treat disease. Here we report the discovery and characterization of ginsentides, a novel family of cysteine and glycine-rich peptides derived from the three most widely-used ginseng species: Panax ginseng, Panax quinquefolius, and Panax notoginseng. Using proteomic and transcriptomic methods, we identified 14 ginsentides, TP1-TP14 which consist of 31-33 amino acids and whose expression profiles are species- and tissues-dependent. Ginsentides have an eight-cysteine motif typical of the eight-cysteine-hevein-like peptides (8C-HLP) commonly found in medicinal herbs, but lack a chitin-binding domain. Transcriptomic analysis showed that the three-domain biosynthetic precursors of ginsentides differ from known 8C-HLP precursors in architecture and the absence of a C-terminal protein-cargo domain. A database search revealed an additional 50 ginsentide-like precursors from both gymnosperms and angiosperms. Disulfide mapping and structure determination of the ginsentide TP1 revealed a novel disulfide connectivity that differs from the 8C-HLPs. The structure of ginsentide TP1 is highly compact, with the N- and C-termini topologically fixed by disulfide bonds to form a pseudocyclic structure that confers resistance to heat, proteolysis, and acid and serum-mediated degradation. Together, our results expand the chemical space of natural products found in ginseng and highlight the occurrence, distribution, disulfide connectivity, and precursor architectures of cysteine- and glycine-rich ginsentides as a class of novel non-chitin-binding, non-cargo-carrying 8C-HLPs.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BB3cvlslKqsA%253D%253D&md5=7f6fee62135daa98086fb3702d9a9418
      44. 44
        Kam, A.; Loo, S.; Fan, J.-S.; Sze, S. K.; Yang, D.; Tam, J. P. Roseltide rT7 is a disulfide-rich, anionic, and cell-penetrating peptide that inhibits proteasomal degradation. J. Biol. Chem. 2019, 294, 19604â 19615, Â DOI: 10.1074/jbc.RA119.010796
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        44
        Roseltide rT7 is a disulfide-rich, anionic, and cell-penetrating peptide that inhibits proteasomal degradation
        Kam Antony; Loo Shining; Sze Siu Kwan; Tam James P; Fan Jing-Song; Yang Daiwen
        The Journal of biological chemistry (2019), 294 (51), 19604-19615 ISSN:.
        Disulfide-rich plant peptides with molecular masses of 2-6 kDa represent an expanding class of peptidyl-type natural products with diverse functions. They are structurally compact, hyperstable, and underexplored as cell-penetrating agents that inhibit intracellular functions. Here, we report the discovery of an anionic, 34-residue peptide, the disulfide-rich roseltide rT7 from Hibiscus sabdariffa (of the Malvaceae family) that penetrates cells and inhibits their proteasomal activities. Combined proteomics and NMR spectroscopy revealed that roseltide rT7 is a cystine-knotted, six-cysteine hevein-like cysteine-rich peptide. A pair-wise comparison indicated that roseltide rT7 is >100-fold more stable against protease degradation than its S-alkylated analog. Confocal microscopy studies and cell-based assays disclosed that after roseltide rT7 penetrates cells, it causes accumulation of ubiquitinated proteins, inhibits human 20S proteasomes, reduces tumor necrosis factor-induced IÎºBÎ± degradation, and decreases expression levels of intercellular adhesion molecule-1. Structure-activity studies revealed that roseltide rT7 uses a canonical substrate-binding mechanism for proteasomal inhibition enabled by an IIML motif embedded in its proline-rich and exceptionally long intercysteine loop 4. Taken together, our results provide mechanistic insights into a novel disulfide-rich, anionic, and cell-penetrating peptide, representing a potential lead for further development as a proteasomal inhibitor in anti-cancer or anti-inflammatory therapies.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BB3Mjpt1enuw%253D%253D&md5=b9ef60fa88d78c6b3235566d2e1684d3

        Zareisedehizadeh, S.; Tan, C. H.; Koh, H. L. A review of botanical characteristics, traditional usage, chemical components, pharmacological activities, and safety of pereskia bleo (kunth) DC. Evid. Based Complement. Alternat. Med. 2014, 2014, 326107 Â DOI: 10.1155/2014/326107
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar

        A Review of Botanical Characteristics, Traditional Usage, Chemical Components, Pharmacological Activities, and Safety of Pereskia bleo (Kunth) DC
        Zareisedehizadeh Sogand; Koh Hwee-Ling; Tan Chay-Hoon
        Evidence-based complementary and alternative medicine : eCAM (2014), 2014 (), 326107 ISSN:1741-427X.
        Pereskia bleo, a leafy cactus, is a medicinal plant native to West and South America and distributed in tropical and subtropical areas. It is traditionally used as a dietary vegetable, barrier hedge, water purifier, and insect repellant and for maintaining health, detoxification, prevention of cancer, and/or treatment of cancer, hypertension, diabetes, stomach ache, muscle pain, and inflammatory diseases such as dermatitis and rheumatism. The aim of this paper was to provide an up-to-date and comprehensive review of the botanical characteristics, traditional usage, phytochemistry, pharmacological activities, and safety of P. bleo. A literature search using MEDLINE (via PubMed), Science direct, Scopus and Google scholar and China Academic Journals Full-Text Database (CNKI) and available eBooks and books in the National University of Singapore libraries in English and Chinese was conducted. The following keywords were used: Pereskia bleo, Pereskia panamensis, Pereskia corrugata, Rhodocacus corrugatus, Rhodocacus bleo, Cactus panamensis, Cactus bleo, Spinach cactus, wax rose, Perescia, and Chinese rose. This review revealed the association between the traditional usage of P. bleo and reported pharmacological properties in the literature. Further investigation on the pharmacological properties and phytoconstituents of P. bleo is warranted to further exploit its potentials as a source of novel therapeutic agents or lead compounds.

        Arnison, Paul G.; Bibb, Mervyn J.; Bierbaum, Gabriele; Bowers, Albert A.; Bugni, Tim S.; Bulaj, Grzegorz; Camarero, Julio A.; Campopiano, Dominic J.; Challis, Gregory L.; Clardy, Jon; Cotter, Paul D.; Craik, David J.; Dawson, Michael; Dittmann, Elke; Donadio, Stefano; Dorrestein, Pieter C.; Entian, Karl-Dieter; Fischbach, Michael A.; Garavelli, John S.; Goeransson, Ulf; Gruber, Christian W.; Haft, Daniel H.; Hemscheidt, Thomas K.; Hertweck, Christian; Hill, Colin; Horswill, Alexander R.; Jaspars, Marcel; Kelly, Wendy L.; Klinman, Judith P.; Kuipers, Oscar P.; Link, A.         Natural Product Reports (2013), 30 (1), 108-160CODEN: NPRRDF; ISSN:0265-0568. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        This review presents recommended nomenclature for the biosynthesis of ribosomally synthesized and post-translationally modified peptides (RiPPs), a rapidly growing class of natural products. The current knowledge regarding the biosynthesis of the >20 distinct compd. classes is also reviewed, and commonalities are discussed.

        Crystal structure of the complex of human epidermal growth factor and receptor extracellular domains
        Ogiso, Hideo; Ishitani, Ryuichiro; Nureki, Osamu; Fukai, Shuya; Yamanaka, Mari; Kim, Jae-Hoon; Saito, Kazuki; Sakamoto, Ayako; Inoue, Mio; Shirouzu, Mikako; Yokoyama, Shigeyuki
        Cell (Cambridge, MA, United States) (2002), 110 (6), 775-787CODEN: CELLB5; ISSN:0092-8674. (Cell Press)
        Epidermal growth factor (EGF) regulates cell proliferation and differentiation by binding to the EGF receptor (EGFR) extracellular region, comprising domains I-IV, with the resultant dimerization of the receptor tyrosine kinase. In this study, the crystal structure of a 2:2 complex of human EGF and the EGFR extracellular region has been detd. at 3.3 Ã resoln. EGFR domains I-III are arranged in a C shape, and EGF is docked between domains I and III. The 1:1 EGFâ¢EGFR complex dimerizes through a direct receptorâ¢receptor interaction, in which a protruding Î²-hairpin arm of each domain II holds the body of the other. The unique "receptor-mediated dimerization" was verified by EGFR mutagenesis.

        Wang, X.; Ge, J.; Tredget, E. E.; Wu, Y. The mouse excisional wound splinting model, including applications for stem cell transplantation. Nat. Protoc. 2013, 8, 302, Â DOI: 10.1038/nprot.2013.002
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        48
        The mouse excisional wound splinting model, including applications for stem cell transplantation
        Wang, Xusheng; Ge, Jianfeng; Tredget, Edward E.; Wu, Yaojiong
        Nature Protocols (2013), 8 (2), 302-309CODEN: NPARDW; ISSN:1750-2799. (Nature Publishing Group)
        The mouse excisional wound healing model was used extensively to study wound healing and cutaneous regeneration. However, as mouse skin is mobile, contraction accounts for a large part of wound closure. In the mouse excisional wound splinting model, a splinting ring tightly adheres to the skin around the wound, preventing local skin contraction. The wound therefore heals through granulation and re-epithelialization, a process similar to that occurring in humans. The model, which takes 2-4 wk to carry out, can be used to study the effects of stem cells on cutaneous repair or regeneration. In this protocol, the authors also describe how to implant stem cells onto the wound bed in Matrigel and/or into the surrounding tissue through injection. Serial wound tissue samples at different time points can be harvested to monitor the engraftment and the effects of stem cells in angiogenesis and wound healing.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXit1Krtb0%253D&md5=6099a1a7b080c66b79ac71781edbfccf

        Lee, D.; Lim, J.; Woo, K.-C.; Kim, K.-T. Piperonylic acid stimulates keratinocyte growth and survival by activating epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR). Sci. Rep. 2018, 8, 162, Â DOI: 10.1038/s41598-017-18361-3
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        50
        Piperonylic acid stimulates keratinocyte growth and survival by activating epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR)
        Lee Dohyun; Lim Jinsun; Kim Kyong-Tai; Woo Kyung-Chul; Kim Kyong-Tai
        Scientific reports (2018), 8 (1), 162 ISSN:.
        Epidermal growth factor (EGF) stimulates cell growth, proliferation, and survival. The biological benefits of EGF have been utilized in medical uses for improving wound healing as well as in today's skin cosmetics. EGF has been found in urine, saliva, milk, and plasma, but its efficient isolation remains a difficult task. With technical advances, recombinant protein purification technique has been used for EGF production. However, the recombinant EGF is still expensive and keeping it with stable activity is difficult to be used widely. Thus, a molecule that can mimic the EGF activity would be a useful alternative of EGF. Herein, we have discovered that a natural small molecule piperonylic acid shows EGF-like activity in HaCaT keratinocytes. Piperonylic acid induced EGF receptor (EGFR) activation and resulted in serial activation of the downstream modulators. The activated signaling pathway eventually up-regulated gene expression of egr-1, c-fos, c-jun, and c-myc, which are involved in cell growth and survival. Moreover, piperonylic acid showed promoting role in keratinocyte growth and survival from UVB-induced cellular damages. This study has revealed the EGF-like activity of piperonylic acid and proposed that the piperonylic acid could be a promising component for skin wound healing agents or cosmetic ingredient.

        Galantino, M.; Cristiani, C.; Vaghi, F.; Liu, W.; Zhang, J.; Tam, J. D-amino acid scan of endothelin: importance of amino acids adjacent to cysteinyl residues in isomeric selectivity. Pept. Res. 1995, 8, 154â 159
        [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        55
        D-Amino acid scan of endothelin: importance of amino acids adjacent to cysteinyl residues in isomeric selectivity
        Galantino, M.; de Castiglione, R.; Cristiani, C.; Vaghi, F.; Liu, W.; Zhang, J. W.; Tam, J. P.
        Peptide Research (1995), 8 (3), 154-9CODEN: PEREEO; ISSN:1040-5704. (Eaton)
        A systematic approach to map the functionally important determinants of endothelin-1 (ET-1) by a D-amino acid scan is described. Correct orientation of the amino acid side chains was generally of paramount importance both for binding at the ETA receptor and for contracting activity. This was particularly valid for positions 2, 8, 14, 16-21 (the four Cys residues were kept unaltered). Nevertheless, increment of binding affinity was obsd. by inversion of configuration at positions 6, 7, 9 and 10. In addn., [D-Lys9]ET-1 was an agonist about four times more potent than the natural compd. Usually both 1,4- and 1,3-isomers (corresponding, resp., to the correct and misfolded disulfide bridges of ET) were obtained, and usually the isomer formed in larger amt. had the higher HPLC retention time and the higher biol. activity. However, four out of seventeen single-point D-amino acid analogs could be isolated only in one isomeric form. In three cases (D-Ser2, D-Ser4, D-Val12), the inverted amino acid was adjacent to a Cys residue, and in one case (D-Lys9) it was one amino acid apart, thus suggesting a possible effect of the bridged cysteinyl residues in isomeric selectivity.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2MXmtFOht7c%253D&md5=81c628bb4fecf3b547a88890c11ccb91

        Lin, Y. Z.; Ke, X. H.; Tam, J. P. Synthesis and structure-activity study of myxoma virus growth factor. Biochemistry 1991, 30, 3310â 3314, Â DOI: 10.1021/bi00227a020
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
